contentItems.description: The term "Milky Way" in terms of observing the celestial sphere is limited to the hazy band of white light across the night sky. Light originates from unresolved stars and other materials within the galactic plane. Dark regions within the band, such as the Great Rift and the Coalsack, are areas where light from distant stars is blocked by dark nebulae.
contentItems.title: Under the Milky Way

contentItems.description: This is an image of the Milky Way arch emerging from the Cerro Paranal, Chile on the left, and sinking into the Antofagasta's light on the right. Above the Milky Way, the bright object in the center is Jupiter. On the left are the visible Magellanic Clouds.
contentItems.title: Milky Way Arch

contentItems.description: This is an infrared image from NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope showing hundreds of thousands of stars crowded into the swirling core of the Milky Way galaxy. This region cannot be seen in visible light because dust between Earth and the galactic center blocks our view.
contentItems.title: Milky Way IR Spitzer

contentItems.description: The picture depicts the Milky Way center aglow with dust. Our Milky Way is so dusty that we cannot see the center of the galaxy in visible light. When NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope set its infrared eyes ont he galactic center, the image highlights the region's exceptionally bright and dusty clouds lit up by young massive stars.
contentItems.title: Dust in the Center of the Milky Way Galaxy
contentItems.uri: http://czbeta.blob.core.windows.net/images/48624876-0b62-49a7-96ea-4fedb498d486_Dust in the Center of the Milky Way Galaxy.jpg

contentItems.description: This is a panoramic image from the Galactic Infrared Mid-Plane Survey Extraordinaire (GLIMPSE) project. Red clouds indicate the presence of large organic molecules mixed with dust illuminated by nearby star formation. Patches of black are dense obscuring dust clouds, and bright arcs of white throughout the image are massive stellar incubators.
contentItems.title: A Glimpse of the Milky Way Galaxy

contentItems.description: These are two of the first images of ESO's GigaGalaxy Zoom project combined to show the whole panorama of the Milky Way. The top image can be seen with the unaided eye. The bottom image shows a slightly zoomed in image of a more central region observed with an amateur telescope. The galaxy consists of a bar-shaped core region surrounded by a disk of gas, dust and stars forming four distinct arm structures spiraling outward in a logarithmic spiral shape.
contentItems.title: Location of Central Region Observed in Milky Way
contentItems.uri: http://czbeta.blob.core.windows.net/images/ef4195f7-c272-48d2-9219-87ed57d4be1d_Location of Central Region Observed in Milky Way.jpg

contentItems.description: This is an image of the night sky above Paranal taken by astronomer Yuri Beletsky of the European Southern Observatory (ESO) depicting the Milky Way. The planet Jupiter and the star Antares are the two bright objects visible in the center of the image. The laser pointer from Yepun, Unit Telescope number 4, points directly at the Galactic center.
contentItems.title: Milky Way Galaxy in the Night Sky

contentItems.description: This panoramic view of the center of our Milky Way galaxy shows the full cycle of stellar evolution.  A central super-massive black hole called Sagittarius A dominates this crowded, hostile environment. However, stars are able to thrive in this environment, and our galaxy contains hundreds of billions of stars.
contentItems.title: The Center of the Milky Way

contentItems.description: This is a segment of an infrared portrait of dust and stars radiating in the inner Milky Way. The picture, taken with more than 800,000 frames from NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope, was stitched together to create the full image, capturing more than 50 percent of the entire galaxy. The segment extends through the constellations Scorpius, Ara, and Norma.
contentItems.title: Segment of the Milky Way

contentItems.attribution: Artist Nick Risinger. Adapted from NASA images.
contentItems.description: This is an artist's conception of the Milky Way galaxy, otherwise known as home to our Solar System. Its name originates from the appearance of a dim "milky" glowing band across the night sky, in which individual stars cannot be distinguished by the naked eye. This appearance results from the galaxy having a disk-shaped structure that is being viewed edge-on.
contentItems.title: Milky Way Galaxy

exhibits.title: The Birth of the Milky Way Galaxy

contentItems.attribution: NASA, ESA, Digitized Sky Survey, and L. Bedin (STScI)
contentItems.description: One of the oldest open clusters of stars known, NGC 6791 contains thousands of stars recently measured to be about 8 billion years old. These stars are relatively dirty - the minuscule amounts of heavy elements are high relative to most other star clusters. Older stars are supposed to be metal poor, since metals have only been slowly accumulating in the Milky Way. Because of this enigma, NGC 6791 has become one of the most studied open clusters and a possible example of how stars might evolve in the centers of galaxies.
contentItems.title: NGC 6791

contentItems.description: A red giant is a luminous giant star of low or intermediate mass (roughly 0.5–10 solar masses) in a late phase of stellar evolution. The outer atmosphere is inflated and tenuous, making the radius immense and the surface temperature low, somewhere from 5,000 K lower. This is what will happen to our sun in approximately 5-6 billion years. At that point, the sun will become so large that it will envelop the entire solar system. The increase in size to scale is shown in the bottom right corner.
contentItems.title: Type of Star: Red Giant

contentItems.description: This image, taken in ultraviolet, visible, and red light by Hubble's Wide Field Camera 3, spans about 100 light-years. It shows a large stellar nursery only a few million years old. This nursery is a type of interstellar cloud whose density and size permits the formation of molecules, most commonly molecular hydrogen. These conditions are perfect for the formation of stars. The early Universe may have had many such nurseries.
contentItems.title: A Large Stellar Nursery

contentItems.description: This hand colored map was engraved by W. G. Evans in 1856 for Burritt's Atlas to Illustrate the Geography of the Heavens. His work was based off of Pardies and Doppelmayr, and depicts the Northern night sky between the months of July and September. It includes the Zodiac signs Scorpio (the Scorpion), Sagittarius (the Archer), Capricorn (the Goat), Serpentarins (the Serpent Bearer) and Taurus (the Bull). The Zodiac refers to the thin band along the ecliptic composed of the Zodiac signs and constellations. The zodiac is divided into twelve different signs each of which is 30 degrees long. It is believed that the concept of the zodiac evolved from Babylonian astronomy, and was later influenced by Hellenistic astronomy.
contentItems.title: The Constellations

contentItems.description: Part 1 examines the conditions that led up to the first stars lighting up. By two hundred million years after the Big Bang, the Universe had become a very dark and cold place. Suddenly 'hot spots' of light and energy appeared from the darkness. Where did they come from?
contentItems.title: Threshold 2: Origins of The First Stars - Part 1

contentItems.description: The right panel is an image from NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope of stars and galaxies in the Ursa Major constellation. This infrared image covers a region of space so large that light would take up to 100 million years to travel across it. The left panel is the same image after stars, galaxies and other sources were masked out. The remaining background light is from a period of time when the universe was less than one billion years old, and most likely originated from the universe's very first groups of objects -- either huge stars or voracious black holes. Darker shades in the image on the left correspond to dimmer parts of the background glow, while yellow and white show the brightest light.
contentItems.title: The Universe's First Light

contentItems.description: In larger stars, fusion continues until the iron core has grown so large (more than 1.4 solar masses) that it can no longer support its own mass. This core will suddenly collapse releasing a burst of inverse beta decay, or electron capture. The shock wave formed by this sudden collapse causes the rest of the star to explode in a supernova. Supernovae are so bright that they may briefly outshine the star's entire home galaxy. Most of the matter in the star is blown away by the supernova explosion and what remains will be a neutron star (which sometimes manifests itself as a pulsar or X-ray burster) or, in the case of the largest stars (large enough to leave a stellar remnant greater than roughly 4 solar masses), a black hole.
contentItems.title: Oldest Recorded Supernova

contentItems.description: A black hole is a region of spacetime from which nothing, not even light, can escape. The theory of general relativity predicts that a sufficiently compact mass will deform spacetime to form a black hole. Around a black hole there is a mathematically defined surface called an event horizon that marks the point of no return. It is called "black" because it absorbs all the light that hits the horizon, reflecting nothing, just like a perfect black body in thermodynamics. Quantum mechanics predicts that black holes emit radiation like a black body with a finite temperature. This temperature is inversely proportional to the mass of the black hole, making it difficult to observe this radiation for black holes of stellar mass or greater. This is a drawing of a black hole depicting the accretion lines.
contentItems.title: Black Hole

contentItems.description: In Part 2, you’ll learn how gravity causes temperatures to increase radically, triggering the process of fusion that creates stars. You’ll explore why this is regarded as a major threshold of increasing complexity. Stars became the first complex, stable entities in the Universe, with the capacity to generate energy for millions or billions of years. You'll explore how stars were produced from the simple matter permeating the early universe and discover how stars gathered together to form galaxies, clusters and superclusters. The creation of stars illustrates how the right 'Goldilocks Conditions' enabled entirely new things to appear.
contentItems.title: Threshold 2: Origins of The First Stars - Part 2

contentItems.description: A white dwarf, also called a degenerate dwarf, is a small star composed mostly of electron-degenerate matter. They are very dense; a white dwarf's mass is comparable to that of the Sun and its volume is comparable to that of the Earth. Its faint luminosity comes from the emission of stored thermal energy. White dwarfs are thought to be the final evolutionary state of all stars whose mass is not high enough to become a neutron star—over 97% of the stars in our galaxy. This is an image of Sirius A and Sirius B captured by the Hubble Space Telescope. Sirius B, which is a white dwarf, can be seen as a faint pinprick of light to the lower left of the much brighter Sirius A.
contentItems.title: Type of Star: White Dwarf

contentItems.description: In this video you will learn how star formation starts over great distances of space with gravity pulling together prodigious amounts of hydrogen atoms. With the increase in heat and density, action moves to the subatomic level where hydrogen is compacted to the point of nuclear fusion. Understanding the four fundamental forces is helpful to understanding how the nuclear reactions at the heart of star formation are dependent on very specific conditions.
contentItems.title: Salman Kahn Explains the Birth of Stars

contentItems.description: 500 km across, Vesta is a rock that orbits around Mars. The rock contains a rugged surface as well as a single crater that spans nearly the entire length of the asteroid. Evidence indicates that Vesta underwent a tremendous splintering collision about a billion years ago. In October 1960 a piece of Vesta fell to Earth and was recovered in Australia.
contentItems.title: False Color Topography of Vesta's South Pole

contentItems.description: Composite image also known as  galaxy cluster 1E 0657-56. Background image of visible light came from the Magellan and Hubble Space Telescope. The pink overlay shows X-ray emission images from the Chandra Telescope. The blue color comes from the mass distribution of the clusters calculated from gravitational lensing effects.
contentItems.title: Bullet Cluster

contentItems.attribution: Left panel: D.Alexander et al. S.Chapman et al. T.Hayashino et al. J.Geach et al. Right Illustration: M.Weiss
contentItems.description: Glowing hydrogen gas is shown by a Lyman-alpha optical image (coloured yellow), a galaxy is visible in a broadband optical image (white) and an infra-red image (red). The blue (x-ray) shows evidence for a growing black hole. Four other active black holes in blobs are also seen. On the right is an artist's representation of what one of the galaxies inside a blob might look like at close distance.
contentItems.title: Lyman Alpha Blob

contentItems.description: Salman Khan explains the Big Bang and how the universe grew to what it is today. He tells the story of how the name "Big Bang" was coined, and how the theory grew to exist. Khan also discusses the "edge" of the Universe.
contentItems.title: Khan Academy: The Big Bang Theory

contentItems.description: Monsignor Georges Henri Joseph Édouard Lemaître (July, 17 1894 – June, 20 1966) was a Belgian priest, astronomer and professor of physics at the Catholic University of Leuven. He was the first person to propose the theory of the expansion of the Universe, widely misattributed to Edwin Hubble. He was also the first to derive what is now known as Hubble's law and made the first estimation of what is now called the Hubble constant which he published in 1927, two years before Hubble's article. Lemaître also proposed what became known as the Big Bang theory of the origin of the Universe, which he called his 'hypothesis of the primeval atom'.
contentItems.title: Georges Lemaître

contentItems.description: The inflationary theory as an augmentation to the Big Bang theory was first proposed by Alan Guth of MIT. Inflation solves the 'horizon problem' by making the early universe much more compact than was assumed in the standard model. Given such smaller size, causal contact (i.e., thermal communication) would have been possible among all regions of the early universe.
contentItems.title: Big Bang Manifold

contentItems.description: In this logarithmic time scale, Waltar Alvarez depicts the early Inflation period, or rapid exponential expansion, of the Universe which took place from the first 10^-36 second to 10^-32 second. Then came the Electroweak epoch which lasted until 10^-12 second, the Quark epoch which lasted until the 10^-6 second, the Hadron epoch which ended in the first second of the Universe, and the Lepton epoch which lasted until the third minute. The Photon Epoch lasted for the next 240,000 years, followed by the long Dark Ages.
contentItems.title: Logarithmic time scale of the first billion years

contentItems.description: Katie Freese discusses what the Big Bang really entailed, and questions whether or not it makes sense to ask what came before the Big Bang. She proposes different theories to help explain what physics fails to do, such as entanglement or string theory. She suggests however, that in order to fully understand the initial moment of the Big Bang we would need a unifying theory of quantum gravity.
contentItems.title: What Came Before the Big Bang

contentItems.description: This is an artist's imagination of how the Big Bang may have appeared. The thicker paint and varying colors could possibly represent early fluctuations in temperature which eventually led to the creation of matter. The swirls on the outside represent the evolution of the Universe as early stars and galaxies began to appear.
contentItems.title: Picturing the Big Bang

contentItems.description: This graph depicts the possible fates of the Universe. The "Big Crunch", Ω>1 on the graph, hypothesized a universe dominated by matter in which gravity will eventually overcome the expanding forces of the Universe. This Universe would end similarly to the Big Bang, in a Big Crunch in which everything would once more come together. Other predictions envisioned a universe that would gradually slow down in its acceleration, or continue steadily at the same rate. However, with the discovery of dark energy as the dominating force in the Universe, it was discovered that the Universe is actually accelerating in its expansion.
contentItems.title: Fate of the Universe

contentItems.description: This is an artist's rendering of the timeline of the Universe. It depicts the initial inflation of the Universe, the release of the cosmic background radiation, and the creation of the stars and galaxies. It also shows the current accelerated expansion of the Universe due to dark energy.
contentItems.title: Timeline of the Universe

contentItems.description: In this video, David Christian will explain what happened during the Big Bang and the early stages of the Universe. The Big Bang is the accepted scientific theory for the beginning of the Universe. Over the last 90 years scientists have developed an evidence-based understanding of the Big Bang and its significance.
contentItems.title: David Christian Explains the Big Bang

contentItems.description: In this video Michio Kaku discusses the early moments of the Big Bang, and the eventual release of the microwave background radiation. However, physicists aren't satisfied with the current understanding of the very first instant of the Big Bang. He hopes that the Large Hadron Collider will be able to give us new insights into space, time, energy, and matter.
contentItems.title: The Large Hadron Collider and the Big Bang

contentItems.attribution: NASA, ESA, CXC, M. Bradac (University of California, Santa Barbara), and S. Allen (Stanford University)
contentItems.description: NASA's Hubble Space Telescope and Chandra X-ray Observatory captured a powerful collision of galaxy clusters. The collision has separated dark from ordinary matter. This was detected previously in the Bullet Clusters, showing that the Bullet Cluster case was not an anomalous case.
contentItems.title: MACS J0025

contentItems.description: Taken by the Hubble Space Telescope, NGC 6752 holds over 100 thousand stars in a sphere about 100 light-years in diameter. The Hubble image frame spans the central 10 or so light-years and resolves stars near the dense cluster core. A remarkable fraction of the stars near the cluster's core are multiple star systems, supporting arguments that star mergers and collisions in the dense stellar environment can create the cluster's blue straggler stars.
contentItems.title: NGC 6752

contentItems.attribution: NASA/Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory/Smithsonian Institution/Carnegie Institution of Washington
contentItems.description: The Rembrandt impact basin was discovered by the robotic MESSENGER spacecraft's 2008 October flyby of the Solar System's innermost planet. It is possibly the youngest large impact basin on the planet. Data is interpreted as indicating a relatively active and volcanic past for Mercury that includes surface tectonics.
contentItems.title: Rembrandt Crater Mosaic

contentItems.description: Oxygen, represented by the symbol O, is the element with atomic number 8 and probably the most important to life as we know it. Oxygen is a member of the chalcogen group on the periodic table and is a highly reactive nonmetallic element that readily forms compounds (notably oxides) with almost all other elements. Oxygen is a strong oxidizing agent and has the second highest electronegativity of all the elements after fluorine. By mass, oxygen is the third most abundant element in the universe after hydrogen and helium and the most abundant element by mass in the Earth's crust, making up almost half of the crust's mass.
contentItems.title: Oxygen

contentItems.description: Hydrogen is the chemical element with atomic number 1. It is represented by the symbol H. With an average atomic weight of 1.00794 u (1.007825 u for hydrogen-1), hydrogen is the lightest and most abundant chemical element, constituting roughly 75% of the Universe's chemical elemental mass. Non-remnant stars are mainly composed of hydrogen in its plasma state. Naturally occurring elemental hydrogen is relatively rare on Earth.
contentItems.title: Hydrogen

contentItems.description: Within this large magellanic cloud heavy elements are created. Some fraction of elements beyond helium were created in the Big Bang, as the protons and neutrons collided with each other (lithium, beryllium, and perhaps some boron), but all of the "heavier elements" (heavier than carbon, element number 6) that we see today, were created inside of stars during a series of fusion stages, such as the proton-proton chain, the CNO cycle and the triple-alpha process. Progressively heavier elements are created during the evolution of a star.
contentItems.title: Origins of Heavy Elements

contentItems.description: The periodic table is a tabular display of the chemical elements, organized on a basis of their properties. Elements are presented in increasing atomic number; while rectangular in general outline, gaps are included in the rows or periods to keep elements with similar properties together. For example, the halogens and the noble gases are in columns or groups, forming distinct rectangular areas or blocks. Because the periodic table accurately predicts the properties of various elements and the relations between properties, its use is widespread within chemistry, providing a useful framework for analyzing chemical behavior, as well as in other sciences. Although precursors exist, the current table is generally credited to Dmitri Mendeleev, who developed it in 1869 to illustrate periodic trends in the properties of the then-known elements; the layout has been refined and extended as new elements have been discovered and new theoretical models developed to explain chemical behavior.
contentItems.title: Periodic Table of Elements

contentItems.description: This image depicts the spectral lines of Helium. Helium, represented by the symbol He, is the chemical element with atomic number 2 and an atomic weight of 4.002602. It is a colorless, odorless, tasteless, non-toxic, inert, monatomic gas that heads the noble gas group in the periodic table. Its boiling and melting points are the lowest among the elements and it exists only as a gas except in extreme conditions. Helium is the second lightest element and is the second most abundant element in the observable universe, being present at about 24% of the total elemental mass, which is more than 12 times the mass of all the heavier elements combined.
contentItems.title: Helium

contentItems.description: Salman Khan explains the lifecycle of a massive star. At the end of its life, a massive star will run out of hydrogen and helium to fuse, so it will begin to fuse heavier and heavier elements until it reaches iron, and can no longer support its core. It will then explode into a supernova, creating other elements in the process.
contentItems.title: Lifecycle of Massive Stars

contentItems.description: This is an especially popular allotrope of Carbon: diamond. Carbon is the chemical element with symbol C and atomic number 6. As a member of group 14 on the periodic table, it is nonmetallic and tetravalent — making four electrons available to form covalent chemical bonds. There are three naturally occurring isotopes, with 12C and 13C being stable, while 14C is radioactive, decaying with a half-life of about 5,730 years. Carbon is one of the few elements known since antiquity.
contentItems.title: Carbon

contentItems.description: So far the Universe has been a relatively simple place. In this video, you'll learn how dying stars generate temperatures hot enough to create entirely new elements. Not all stars are the same size. Relatively small stars fade away quietly. Larger stars explode magnificently into supernovae, creating the Goldilocks Conditions necessary to form almost all the chemical elements.
contentItems.title: Threshold 3: Creating New Chemical Elements - Part 1

contentItems.description: In Part 2, you’ll learn why the size of dying stars matters so much. Only very big stars create temperatures high enough to create the rest of the elements. These explode spectacularly, spreading these new elements across huge distances and making the Universe much more complex.
contentItems.title: Threshold 3: Creating New Chemical Elements - Part 2

contentItems.description: This depicts the relative abundance of chemical elements in the Universe. Hydrogen and Helium are by far the most common. Oxygen and Carbon are both also common, while the heavier metals tend to be the most rare.
contentItems.title: Abundance of Elements in the Universe

contentItems.description: The first stars in the Universe turn on at about 400 million years after the Big Bang. A star is a massive, luminous sphere of plasma held together by gravity. A star begins as a collapsing cloud of material composed primarily of hydrogen, helium and trace amounts of heavier elements.
contentItems.title: First Stars

contentItems.description: A timeline of the universe, created at Caltech, but linked on NASA's website as part of the James Webb Space Telescope exhibit. In Big Bang cosmology, reioniation is the process that reionized the matter in the universe after the "dark ages," and is the second of two major phase changes of gas in the universe. The first phase change of hydrogen in the universe occurred due to the cooling of the universe to the point where the rate of recombination of an electron and proton to form neutral hydrogen was higher than the ionization rate of hydrogen. The universe was opaque before recombination.
contentItems.title: Reion Diagram

contentItems.description: The artist illustrates the hottest planet yet observed in the universe. HC 149026b, a "hot Jupiter," is 3700 degrees Fahrenheit (2040 degrees Celcius), about 3 times hotter than the rocky surface of Venus. Astronomers believe that it is absorbing almost all the heat from its star, and reflecting very little light back. Therefore, it may be the blackest known planet in the universe, in addition to the hottest.
contentItems.title: Hot Planet

contentItems.description: An illustration of abstract "slices" of space at different points in time. The size of the universe is being shown in two dimensions, allowing the time axis to be represented. The expansion of the Universe is the increase of distance with time between distant parts of the Universe. It is an intrinsic expansion, defined by the relative separation of parts of the Universe and not by motion "outward" into preexisting space.
contentItems.title: Universe Expansion

contentItems.description: This is a progressive size comparison of the planets in our solar system, our Sun, and some of the larger stars in the Universe. The Sun has a diameter about 100 times that of Earth's and VY Canis Majoris is 1800 times the size of our Sun. Another way to consider size is by volume, in which case one million Earths would fit inside the Sun. Remember that the stars pictured are in different stages of their lives and our Sun will get much bigger in later stages of it's life.
contentItems.title: A Size Comparison of Planets and Stars

contentItems.description: Stars range in size from neutron stars (20-40km) in diameter, to supergiants like Betelgeuse in the Orion constellation (diameter about 650 times larger than the Sun, 900,000,000 km). However, Betelgeuse has a much lower density than the Sun.
contentItems.title: Relative Star Sizes

contentItems.description: This is a pie chart estimating the distribution different substances within the Universe. Dark matter makes up 22% of the mass of the universe and dark energy accounts for 74%, while 'normal' matter (stars, planets, galaxies, and every other form of matter) makes up only 0.4% of the mass of the universe. Dark matter is a currently undetermined type of matter hypothesized to account for a large part of the universe's total mass. It neither emits nor scatters light or other electromagnetic radiation so cannot be seen with telescopes.
contentItems.title: Dark Matter Pie

contentItems.description: This is a timeline of the universe, from the Big Bang, Inflation, and the Dark Ages in the early Universe, to the development of the first stars, galaxies, and planets, to the Accelerated Expansion phase currently taking place. Cosmic microwave background radiation is thermal radiation filling the observable universe almost uniformly. The CMB was first discovered in 1964 by American radio astronomers Arno Penzias and Robert Wilson. CMB is the radiation left over from an early stage in the universe's development and is considered a landmark test of the Big Bang model of the universe.
contentItems.title: Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation Timeline

contentItems.description: The artist's timeline chronicles the history of the universe from its explosive beginning to its mature, present-day state. The Big Bang about 13.7 billion years ago was revealed in the microwave light by NASA's Cosmic Background Explorer and Wilkinson Anistrophy Microwave Probe. After a period of darkness, until about a few hundred million years later, the first light in the universe is believed to have been captured as visible ultraviolet, then red-shifted infrared by the Spitzer telescope. Finally, NASA's Hubble Space Telescope has captured stunning pictures of earlier galaxies.
contentItems.title: Brief History of the Universe

contentItems.attribution: NASA/JPL-Caltech/L. Armus (SSC/Caltech), H. Kline (JPL), Digital Sky Survey
contentItems.description: NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope has detected the building blocks of life in the distant universe. Spitzer observed a faint object located at 3.2 billion light-years with the presence of water and organic molecules. The infrared spectrograph identifying the object's chemical composition and physical properties denotes the presence of silicates, molecular hydrogen, and organic molecules comprised of carbon and hydrogen. Additional features in the spectrum reveals the presence of water ice, carbon dioxide ice and carbon monoxide in both gas and solid forms.
contentItems.title: Galaxy IRAS

contentItems.description: The Type II supernova explosion could be seen 5 billion light years away even with a small telescope. A high mass star began fusing heavy elements in or near its core. They may be energetically more powerful than theirType Ia supernova cousins, but astronomers don't know how to use their intrinsic brightness to calibrate the distance scale of the nearby universe.
contentItems.title: SN 2005ap

exhibits.title: SN 2005ap: The Brightest Supernova Yet Found

contentItems.description: Looking at distant objects is like looking back in time. This large cluster of galaxies (red dots in center), an early galactic metropolis, appears as it was 9.6 billion years ago, only about three billion years after the Big Bang. Astronomers were surprised to find such a well-populated cluster at an era when other clusters tended to be smaller, typically taking much longer to collect enough galaxies to reach such a size.
contentItems.title: An Early Cluster of Galaxies

contentItems.description: Astronomers have spotted a "dust factory" in the spiral galaxy M74 located at the scene of a massive star's explosive death, or supernova. The dust factory (supernova SN 2003gd) is shown at the center of the two small insets from Spitzer's Infrared Array Camera (IRAC). A white arrow points to its exact location. The larger image to the right of the insets is the galaxy M74.
contentItems.title: Supernova Dust Factory in Galaxy M74

contentItems.description: This is an image from NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope. The many pale dots that look like a snowstorm in the night sky, are in fact distant galaxies in the cluster MACS J0717.5+3745. A galaxy is a massive, gravitationally bound system that consists of stars and stellar remnants, interstellar gas and dust, and dark matter.
contentItems.title: Cluster MACS J0717.5+3745

contentItems.attribution: NASA, ESA, CXC, JPL, Caltech and STScI
contentItems.description: The galaxy Messier 101 is a swirling spiral of stars, gas, and dust nearly twice as wide as the Milky Way Galaxy. Spitzer's view in infrared light shows the galaxy's dust lanes as yellow-green filaments. New stars, formed from such dense clouds, glow red, while the rest of the galaxy's stars are less prominent and form a blue haze. Astronomers use visible light to study where and how stars form in spiral galaxies.
contentItems.title: Spiral Galaxy M101

contentItems.description: M33, the Triangulum Galaxy, is the second nearest spiral galaxy to the Milky Way (after M31, the Andromeda Galaxy) and appears at a moderate inclination allowing us to see its internal structure clearly (whereas M31 is oriented nearly edge-on). The Galaxy Explorer imaged M33 as it appears in UV wavelengths, that trace emissions from the atmospheres of hot stars. These observations allow astronomers to compare populations of young, massive stars with other components of the galaxy, such as interstellar dust and gas, on the scale of individual giant molecular clouds.
contentItems.title: Spiral Galaxy M33

contentItems.description: The word galaxy is derived from Greek galaxias meaning "milky," a reference to the Milky Way galaxy. Galaxies contain varying amounts of star systems, star clusters, and types of interstellar clouds. In between them is a sparse interstellar medium of gas, dust, and cosmic rays, with dark matter accounting for around 90% of the mass of most galaxies.
contentItems.title: Messier 81

contentItems.attribution: CHANDRA X-ray Observatory CXC Operated for NASA by SAO
contentItems.description: Galaxy 3C295 is one of the most distant galaxy clusters observed by X-ray telescopes, first discovered as a bright source of radio waves. The cluster is filled with a cloud of fifty million degree gas that radiates strongly in X rays. From the redshift data, we see the galaxy cluster as it was 4.7 billion years ago.
contentItems.title: 3C295

contentItems.attribution: NASA/JPL-Caltech/M. Meixner (STScI) & the SAGE Legacy Team
contentItems.description: This image from NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope shows the Large Magellanic Cloud, a satellite galaxy to the Milky Way. The image allows astronomers a chance to study the lifecycle of stars and dust in a single galaxy. Blue color represents starlight from older stars, while the chaotic, bright regions outside are filled with hot, massive stars. Red color is from dust heated by stars, while scattered red dots are either dusty, old stars or more distant galaxies.
contentItems.title: Large Magellanic Cloud

contentItems.description: NASA's Galaxy Evolution Explorer shows spiral galaxy NGC 1512 slightly northwest of elliptical galaxy NGC 1510. The two galaxies are currently separated by 68,000 light-years, leading astronomers to suspect a close encounter in progress. NGC 1512 has a light blue inner ring formed by the overlapping of two tightly wound spiral arm segments. NGC 1512's outer spiral arm is being distorted by strong gravitational interactions with NGC 1510.
contentItems.title: Spiral Galaxy NGC 1512

contentItems.attribution: NASA Headquarters - Greatest Images of NASA (NASA-HQ-GRIN)
contentItems.description: The galaxy was imaged by the Hubble Space Telescope as part of the HST Key Project on the Extragalactic Distance Scale. The distance to the galaxy was about 60 million light-years. The picture shows the central regions of NGC 4414, typical of most spirals, containing primarily older, yellow and red stars, whereas the outer spiral arms are bluer due to ongoing formation of young, blue stars.
contentItems.title: Spiral Galaxy NGC 4414

contentItems.description: Neptune is the eighth and farthest planet from the Sun in the Solar System. Named for the Roman god of the sea, it is the fourth-largest planet by diameter and the third largest by mass. Neptune is 17 times the mass of Earth and is slightly more massive than its near-twin Uranus, which is 15 times the mass of Earth but not as dense. On average, Neptune orbits the Sun at a distance of 30.1 AU, approximately 30 times the Earth–Sun distance. Its astronomical symbol is ♆, a stylized version of the god Neptune's trident.
contentItems.title: Neptune

contentItems.description: Mercury is the innermost and smallest planet in the Solar System, orbiting the Sun once every 87.969 Earth days. The orbit of Mercury has the highest eccentricity of all the Solar System planets, and it has the smallest axial tilt. It completes three rotations about its axis for every two orbits. The perihelion of Mercury's orbit precesses around the Sun at an excess of 43 arcseconds per century, a phenomenon that was explained in the 20th century by Albert Einstein's General Theory of Relativity.
contentItems.title: Mercury

contentItems.description: Jupiter is the fifth planet from the Sun and the largest planet within the Solar System. It is a gas giant with mass one-thousandth that of the Sun but is two and a half times the mass of all the other planets in our Solar System combined. Jupiter is classified as a gas giant along with Saturn, Uranus and Neptune. Together, these four planets are sometimes referred to as the Jovian or outer planets.
contentItems.title: Jupiter

contentItems.description: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun in the Solar System. Named after the Roman god of war, Mars, it is often described as the "Red Planet" as the iron oxide prevalent on its surface gives it a reddish appearance. Mars is a terrestrial planet with a thin atmosphere, having surface features reminiscent both of the impact craters of the Moon and the volcanoes, valleys, deserts, and polar ice caps of Earth. The rotational period and seasonal cycles of Mars are likewise similar to those of Earth, as is the tilt that produces the seasons. Mars is the site of Olympus Mons, the highest known mountain within the Solar System, and of Valles Marineris, the largest canyon. The smooth Borealis basin in the northern hemisphere covers 40% of the planet and may be a giant impact feature.
contentItems.title: Mars

contentItems.description: From its discovery in 1930 until 2006, Pluto was classified as a planet. In the late 1970s, following the discovery of other minor planets in the outer Solar System and the recognition of Pluto's relatively low mass, its status as a major planet began to be questiond. In 2006, the International Astronomical Union defined what it means to be a "planet" within the Solar System: 1) the oject must be in orbit around the Sun; 2) the object must be massive enough to be a sphere by its own gravitational force; and 3) it must have cleared the neighborhood around its orbit. Pluto fails to meet the third condition, since its mass in only 0.07 times that of the mass of the other objects in its orbit. Pluto was then reclassified as a "dwarf planet".
contentItems.title: Why Is Pluto No Longer a Planet?

contentItems.description: Earth is the third planet from the Sun, fifth-largest of the eight planets in the Solar System, and the densest. It is also the largest of the Solar System's four terrestrial planets. It is sometimes referred to as the world, the Blue Planet, or by its Latin name, Terra.
contentItems.title: Earth

contentItems.description: Venus is the second planet from the Sun, orbiting it every 224.7 Earth days. The planet is named after Venus, the Roman goddess of love and beauty. After the Moon, it is the brightest natural object in the night sky, reaching an apparent magnitude of −4.6, bright enough to cast shadows. Because Venus is an inferior planet from Earth, it never appears to venture far from the Sun: its elongation reaches a maximum of 47.8°. Venus reaches its maximum brightness shortly before sunrise or shortly after sunset, for which reason it has been known as the Morning Star or Evening Star.
contentItems.title: Venus

contentItems.description: Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun and the second largest planet in the Solar System, after Jupiter. Named after the Roman god Saturn, its astronomical symbol (♄) represents the god's sickle. Saturn is a gas giant with an average radius about nine times that of Earth. While only 1/8 the average density of Earth, with its larger volume Saturn is just over 95 times more massive than Earth.
contentItems.title: Saturn

contentItems.description: Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun. It has the third-largest planetary radius and fourth-largest planetary mass in the Solar System. It is named after the ancient Greek deity of the sky Uranus. Though it is visible to the naked eye like the five classical planets, it was never recognized as a planet by ancient observers because of its dimness and slow orbit. Sir William Herschel announced its discovery on March 13, 1781, expanding the known boundaries of the Solar System for the first time in modern history. Uranus was also the first planet discovered with a telescope.
contentItems.title: Uranus

contentItems.description: Salman Kahn describes the Solar System. He attempts to show the relative size and distance of the various planets in their orbits around the Sun. He also describes the planetary motion, and their various appearances.
contentItems.title: Scale of the Solar System

contentItems.description: This picture was taken from the Hubble Space Telescope. The appearance of several strangely elongated galaxies and five fully bright quasars are actually an entire cluster of galaxies acting as a gigantic gravitational lens that distorts and multiplies bright objects that are far in the distance. The gravity of a galaxy cluster SDSS J1004+4122 warps and magnifies the light from a distant quasar.
contentItems.title: A Five Quasar Gravitational Lens

contentItems.description: In Part 3, David Christian considers the discovery of other solar systems in our own Milky Way galaxy
contentItems.title: Threshold 4: Origins of The Earth and The Solar System - Part 3

contentItems.description: Salman Khan explains how the Earth, the sun, and the solar system formed from a nearby supernova.
contentItems.title: Earth Formation

contentItems.description: This illustration depicts the approximate relative sizes of the planets, but not their correct distances from each other. Outward from the Sun, there is Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune.
contentItems.title: Relative Size of the Solar System

contentItems.description: Part 2 focuses on the formation of our Sun from a protoplanetary disk, or proplyd, and the subsequent development of our Solar System.
contentItems.title: Threshold 4: Origins of The Earth and The Solar System - Part 2

contentItems.description: The Sun is the star at the center of the Solar System. It is almost perfectly spherical and consists of hot plasma interwoven with magnetic fields. It has a diameter of about 1,392,000 km, about 109 times that of Earth, and its mass (about 2×1030 kilograms, 330,000 times that of Earth) accounts for about 99.86% of the total mass of the Solar System. Chemically, about three quarters of the Sun's mass consists of hydrogen, while the rest is mostly helium. The remainder (1.69%, which nonetheless equals 5,628 times the mass of Earth) consists of heavier elements, including oxygen, carbon, neon, iron, and others.
contentItems.title: The Sun

contentItems.attribution: David Benjamin and David Christian lecture slides
contentItems.description: David Christian and Craig Benjamin's lecture slide depicts the structure of Earth. The metallic core gave the earth a magnetic field which shielded it from solar radiation.
contentItems.title: Structure of the Earth

contentItems.description: Salman Khan illustrates the relative size and distance of the sun and the earth.
contentItems.title: Scale of Earth and Sun

contentItems.description: In Part 1 David Christian gives a chemistry lesson and explains how elements link up to form more complex molecules. These new materials were necessary for creating our solar system
contentItems.title: Threshold 4: Origins of The Earth and The Solar System - Part 1

exhibits.title: Threshold 4: Origins of The Earth and The Solar System

timeline.title: Oxygen content of the Atmosphere (H.D. Holland, 2006)

contentItems.description: Located in the Gawler Ranges of South Australia, the Acraman crater is marked today by the dry lake Lake Acraman. Since its creation approximately 580 million years ago, the crater has undergone heavy erosion. Its age and original size have thus been inferred by indirect means through analysis of ejecta and other geological evidence, resulting in sometimes controversial estimates.
contentItems.title: Satellite image of Acraman crater

contentItems.description: The Sudbury Basin is the second-largest known impact crater on Earth, occurring an estimated 1.849 billion years ago. The Basin is located in the city of Greater Sudbury in Ontario, Canada. After impact, the crater was filled with mineral-rich magma, which led to the Sudbury region becoming one of the world’s largest mining communities, particularly for nickel and copper ores. The region’s soil, also rich in minerals, is among the most fertile land in Northern Ontario.
contentItems.title: Satellite image of Sudbury Basin

contentItems.description: Located in the Free State province of central South Africa, the Vredefort crater is the largest known impact structure on Earth. Estimated at approximately 2.023 billion years old, Vredefort is also the second oldest known impact crater on Earth, after the  Suavjärvi crater in Russia. The town of Vredefort is situated near the centre of the 250-300 km crater. In 2005, the Vredefort crater was named a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
contentItems.title: Satellite image of Vredefort crater

contentItems.description: The largest known impact crater in the United States, the Chesapeake Bay crater was formed by a bolide impact on the eastern coast of North America approximately 35 million years ago. Erosion and movement of the sediments surrounding the impact have helped shaped Chesapeake Bay, the largest estuary in the US. The crater is an example of one of the best-preserved marine impact structures on Earth.
contentItems.title: Boundary map of Chesapeake Bay crater

contentItems.description: The fifth-largest known crater on Earth, the Manicouagan Crater in Quebec, Canada was thought to have been formed by a 5 km asteroid that struck the Earth in the Triassic Period, about 215 million years ago. The multi-ring crater, approximately 100 km across, has left a distinctive geologic mark on the landscape, with the annular lake, the Manicouagan Reservoir surrounding René-Levasseur Island. Easily visible from space, this circular structure has been dubbed the “eye of Quebec”. This image of the Manicouagan Reservoir in winter was taken from Space Shuttle Columbia on mission STS-9 in December, 1983.
contentItems.title: Manicouagan crater from space

contentItems.description: This is a computer-generated three-dimensional gravity map of the Chicxulub crater. Buried under Mexico’s Yucatán peninsula, the 180 km-wide crater is one of the largest and most studied impact structures on Earth. Dated to about 65 million years ago, the Chicxulub crater lends strong evidence to the theory that a violent impact caused the Cretaceous-Paleogene mass extinction event, which is most noted for wiping out the dinosaurs. First postulated by Luis and Walter Alvarez at the University of California, Berkeley, the theory has since been supported by extensive paleontological, geophysical/chemical, and climatological data, and is now widely accepted in the scientific community.
contentItems.title: Gravity map of the Chicxulub crater

contentItems.description: The Popigai crater in Siberia, Russia is estimated to have been formed in the late Eocene, approximated 35.7 million years ago. Notably, it is thought the immense heat and shock pressures of the impact instantly transformed graphite on the ground into diamond, explaining the prevalence of the precious stone in and around the crater. There is also a slight possibility that the similarly-aged Chesapeake Bay impact crater on the eastern seaboard of the United States was formed simultaneously with the Popigai crater.
contentItems.title: Satellite image of Popigai crater

contentItems.description: Detailed stratigraphic studies of Cretaceous black shales from many parts of the world indicated two oceanic anoxic events, one at the Cenomanian-Turonian boundary, sometimes called the Bonarelli Event.
contentItems.title: Italy Outcrop

contentItems.description: Ocean anoxic events occur when the Earth's oceans become completely depleted of oxygen below the surface levels. Geological records shows that anoxic events happened many times in the past and may have caused mass extinctions, some so characteristic that they were used as time markers in biostratigraphic dating.
contentItems.title: Bonarelli Layer

contentItems.description: Gubbio is famous among geologists and palaeontologists as the discovery place of the "Gubbio layer", a sedimentary layer enriched in iridium that was exposed by a roadcut outside of town. The band of sediment marks the Cretaceous–Paleogene boundary, also known as the K–T boundary or K–Pg boundary.
contentItems.title: Gubbio Quarry

contentItems.description: The Carboniferous is known for its coal-bearing deposits.  Swamps like these produced much of the carbon that was trapped and later turned to coal.
contentItems.title: Carboniferous Coal Swamps

contentItems.attribution: Craig Benjamin and David Christian lecture slides
contentItems.description: Craig Benjamin and David Christian's lecture slide shows an artist's rendering of how the earth might possibly have looked during the early Hadean Eon.
contentItems.title: Hadean Eon Representation

contentItems.description: Part 2 explains the relationship between the different qualities of life, takes a closer look at DNA and introduces Charles Darwin’s work on the theory of evolution.
contentItems.title: Threshold 5: Origins of Life - Part 2

contentItems.description: Fossilized stromatolites, an early Pre-Cambrian form of life.  Stromatolites are considered to be some of the first evidence of life on Earth.
contentItems.title: Stromatolites

contentItems.attribution: Craig Benjamin and David Christian lecture slides
contentItems.description: Craig Benjamin and David Christian outline the 8 major steps in the evolution of life on Earth.
contentItems.title: 8 Important Steps

contentItems.description: In Part 1, David Christian explains the Goldilocks Conditions that helped life form and prosper.
contentItems.title: Threshold 5: Origins of Life - Part 1

contentItems.description: Round Top is an extinct volcano in the Berkeley Hills, just east of Oakland, California. Its elevation is 1761 feet/ 537m. 10 million years ago, the preserve contains a volcanic center that produced most of the lavas that underlie the East Bay ridges from Inspiration Point in Tilden Regional Park to Moraga. This event of local volcanism was referred to by geologists as the Moraga Volcanics.
contentItems.title: Die Gartenlaube (The Garden Arbor)

contentItems.description: Sexual reproduction enabled a greater amount of variation in cells. By combining the genetic information of two parent cells, the offspring were given a greater amount of genetic variability allowing them to cope with different environments and have a back up set of genes in case of damage. It also set the foundation for sexual selection which is now a very strong evolutionary force, creating a myriad of different organs, capabilities and behaviors.
contentItems.title: Haploid vs. Diploid

contentItems.description: Salman Khan explains the process of sexual reproduction. Mitosis is the process by which a eukaryotic cell separates chromosomes in its nucleus into two identical sets, in two separate nuclei. Meiosis is a type of cell division necessary for sexual reproduction. Sexual reproduction is the creation of a new organism by combining the generic material of two organisms.
contentItems.title: Mitosis, Meiosis and Sexual Reproduction

contentItems.description: In this picture we can see the cytoskeleton of the several eukaryotic cells fluorescing. This skeleton holds cells together and maintains their integrity. It serves many of the same functions that a skeleton on multicellular organisms serves. The phospholipid bilayer on its own would not be enough to maintain the integrity of the cell so microtubules and microfilaments made of tubulin and actin protein polymers respectively create a network that keep cells shape. In fact these same proteins are what allow for many types of cellular locomotion such as pseudopod motion. Many proteins move across these tubes and filaments in order to move objects accurately to their destination. In animal cells, structures known as centrosomes made up of these tubes help guide mitosis, or cellular division.
contentItems.title: Cytoskeleton: The backbone and highways of the cell

contentItems.description: Cellular membranes are made of a special kind of lipid called phospholipids. These have a head which is made up of a diglyceride and phosphate group, making it polar and therefore hydrophilic. This means it is attracted to water and can be dissolved in it easily. They also have a tail which is made up of a long chain of hydrocarbons making it non-polar. This means it is similar chemically to oily substances and has a difficult time dissolving in water. This makes it hydrophobic and avoid water. When millions of these molecules are put together, they create membranes that have two layers of these lipids, with the heads facing outward toward the water, and the tails facing inward towards each other avoiding the water. They can hold themselves together fairly well because of these inter-molecular forces but are also slightly permeable to water which allows for osmosis to take place.
contentItems.title: Phospholipid Membranes

contentItems.description: Mitochondrias are the sites in cells that produce all the energy that the cell needs to carry out it's functions. The energy it generates comes from breaking high energy bonds in organic molecules, which is released when these molecules form new low energy bonds as CO2 and H2O. The mitochondria uses that differential to generate ATP, the energy currency of the cell. The basic breakdown of glucose occurs in three steps: glycolysis, the citric acid cycle and oxidative phosphorylation. Glycolysis actually takes place outside of the mitochondria and involves the splitting of the glucose molecule in half. These halves then move into the mitochondria into the Citric Acid cycle. There the complete breakdown occurs. Finally all these electron carrier molecules pass through ATP synthase and for a total of around 32 ATP per glucose molecule. It is thought mitochondria originally were separate organisms that evolved inside eukaryotic cells and are now endosymbionts.
contentItems.title: Mitochondria: The power-plants of cells

contentItems.description: Once the genetic information in the cell leaves the nucleus as mRNA it needs to be converted into proteins somehow before this information can be expressed, since proteins are what actually give organisms their traits. To do this, the cell utilizes ribosomes, organelles that are made up of both protein and rRNA, or ribosomal RNA. It is what you would call a ribozyme since it is an enzyme (protein) and a ribonucelotide. The way translation occurs is that the mRNA is fed through the ribosome and this ribosome reads it, three letters at a time. There are 64 different combinations, but only 20 amino acids that make up all proteins, so some amino acids have several three letter codes. As these codes are read, tRNAs with complimentary three letter sequences and one amino acid bound to them enter the ribosome from the top and begin assembling a chain of amino acids that will later become a protein.
contentItems.title: Ribosomes: Protein Factories

contentItems.description: Eukaryote cells include a variety of membrane-bound structures, collectively referred to as the endomembrane system. Simple compartments, called vesicles or vacuoles, can form by budding off other membranes. Many cells ingest food and other materials through a process of endocytosis, where the outer membrane invaginates and then pinches off to form a vesicle. It is probable that most other membrane-bound organelles are ultimately derived from such vesicles.
contentItems.title: Internal Membrane

contentItems.description: The ER is a versatile organelle that fulfills a variety of vital functions in the cell depending on the metabolic needs. It is a network of membraned tubes with proteins on the surface. These proteins can change in number and variety based on stresses that the cell experiences, giving cells greater flexibility in a changing environment. There are two main types of ER, the rough and the smooth. The rough gains its name from the ribosomes on its surface that give it a grainy look when visualized through a microscope. It helps organize and coordinate protein synthesis. The smooth ER lacks these ribosomes and tends to focus on fat and steroid production as well as metabolizing toxins.
contentItems.title: Endoplasmic Reticulum

contentItems.description: The nucleus is where all the cell's genetic information is stored in the form of chromatin. Chromatin is the cell's DNA wrapped tightly around well packed proteins, that are there to protect the DNA from being degraded. The monomers of chromatin are nucleosomes, that bind together into chromosomes when the cell is ready to divide. The nuclear envelope is a double lipid bilayer that likely originated from an infolding of the cells normal membrane meaning the nuclear membrane is twice as thick as the regular cell membrane. Inside the nucleus, DNA is transcribed into mRNA. Most DNA is not actually genes that code for something important, but rather junk DNA that is there to absorb damage and protect the genes from damage, and then most genes aren't expressed in every cell, only a small subset are. The mRNA acts as a messenger of genetic information that exits the nucleus into the cytoplasm where it can be translated into proteins.
contentItems.title: The Nucleus: The Core of Eukaryotic cells

contentItems.description: Eukaryotes are different from prokaryotes in that they have membrane-bound organelles. This means that they are more compartimentalised and can therefore perform a wider range of chemical reactions. These cells also have a nucleus where DNA is stored and protected. Eukaryotic cells are also generally larger than prokaryotic cells and are the building blocks of all multicellular organisms, such as plants and animals.
contentItems.title: Organelles

contentItems.description: Chloroplasts are not found in animal or fungi cells; only plant and algae cells contain them. They are similar in many ways to mitochondria. It is hypothesized that they have similar origins to mitochondria in that they were originally free living cyanobacteria that were ingested and later evolved within larger eukaryotic cells as endosymbionts. The function of chloroplasts is to generate organic molecules, especially simple sugars such as glucose, from CO2 and H2O. This is an extremely important function ecologically since it recycles inorganic molecules and creates molecules we can gain sustenance from by using solar energy. It carries out its functions through thylakoids and has two sets of reactions: light dependent which use chlorophyll A and B to break down water and create oxygen, and light independent (or Calvin cycle) which actually create the simple sugars and fixes carbon dioxide.
contentItems.title: Chloroplasts: Photosynthesis Centers

contentItems.description: With eukaryotic cells being such complex structures, some kind of sorting mechanism needs to be in place. Proteins created by ribosomes are folded further here and packaged to go to their destinations within or outside the cell. It also plays an important role in the movement of lipids around the cell. Lysosomes, the main digestive sacs within the cell that contain hydrolytic enzymes, are also created here. In addition, proteins that can be found on the surface of cellular membranes often contain carbohydrates attached to them and this is where they are added, through a process called glycosylation.
contentItems.title: The Golgi Apparatus: The post office of the cell

contentItems.description: There was a time when the world went through an enormous glaciation that stretched almost from pole to pole, making the last one that humans experienced seem insignificant in comparison. Around 600 million years ago, the world was thrust into this ice age because much of the CO2 in the atmosphere was sequestered by plankton and taken out of the carbon cycle by being deposited as limestone. This reduction in greenhouse gases caused temperatures to plummet to an extraordinary degree, causing a global winter that only subsided after enough CO2 had been returned to the atmosphere by volcanoes. It is thought that this pressure on life around at the time sped up evolution and created the more resilient body plans that we see today.
contentItems.title: Artist depiction Snowball Earth

contentItems.description: It is still unclear how the first multicellular life appeared. One hypothesis is that colonial protists congregated and began to specialize in their functionality. This specialization would have then proven more beneficial to each individual cell than living independently and at some point the colony started to act more like a single organism and began further specialization. Today the most simple multicellular animals are sponges.
contentItems.title: Cooperation

contentItems.description: It is thought that cycles of extreme glaciation almost to the equator and extreme greenhouse periods would have applied strong selective pressures and driven evolution. The first multicellular life is known as the Ediacaran biota and it predates the more famous Cambrian Explosion event. Many organisms from this period pertain to unknown or extinct lineages; they do not have modern descendants. Most were simple, soft and tubular organisms. Somewhere within this timeframe, all the modern lineages must have appeared and then suddenly diversified during the Cambrian explosion. The first true organs were developed somewhere during this time and can be found in flatworms and higher. They consist of parenchyma tissue which is the main component and stroma which differ but connect the organ to other systems.The development of true organs, rather than just specialized tissues is what ultimately kicked evolution into overdrive and is what makes the Phanaerozoic so full of macroscopic life
contentItems.title: Ediacaran Fauna, Snowball Earth and True organs

contentItems.description: With multicellularity comes the necessity for tight cellular cohesion. As cells started to congregate into larger units, more strain was put on cells to stay together so to account for this, cells evolved different ways of sticking together. Desmosomes made of actin (the proteins that make up muscle cells) or keratin filaments (the proteins that make up your finger nails) are used to form strong connections between two cells. Gap junctions allow for materials to flow more freely through two cells, allowing for better communication. Tight junctions for when cells need to seal off a certain area, creating a barrier forcing everything to pass through the cell wall (like in skin).
contentItems.title: Cellular Junctions

contentItems.description: Though they may at first glance appear to be some for of plant, sponges are in fact classified as animals. They may not move, but they have many of the traits that characterize animals such as cell specialization, heterotrophy and multicellularity among other common animal traits. There is much developmental and biochemical evidence that suggests that the first animals would have been similar to modern day sponges.
contentItems.title: Sponges (Porifera)

contentItems.description: Cnidarians are another primitive group of organisms that are still around today. Jellyfish, sea anemones, corals and hydrozoans are all part of this category. Unlike sponges, these organisms actually have tissue layers, though no true organs. In addition, what separates higher animals from cnidarians is that all cnidarians have radial symmetry (meaning they can be cut into mirror images many different ways whereas things like humans only have one plane of symmetry or left and right sides). They also only have two germ layers from which all other cells originate whereas higher animals have 3 layers. They can be distinguished into medusas if their mouth cavity points down or polyps if it points up.  Some coral are unique and create large colonies that leave huge limestone deposits behind creating the vast reefs we see on tropical islands. Most cnidarians also have poisonous organelles that look like little harpoons called nematocysts that they use to stun their prey.
contentItems.title: Polyps and Medusas (Cnidarians)

contentItems.description: All animals more complex than sponges produce either 2 or 3 germ layers, or cell lines that give rise to all other organs and tissues. Cnidarians have two (endoderm and ectoderm) and everything from humans to insects to earthworms have three (those two plus a mesoderm). These cell lineages are called "multipotent" stem cells because they can become many different kinds of cell types within a certain range. The names are somewhat self explanatory: ectoderm gives rise to the skin, cornea and nervous system, the mesoderm creates the bones and muscles and the endoderm is mainly involved becoming the digestive system.
contentItems.title: Tissues and Germ Layers

contentItems.description: When multicellularity arose something interesting happened known as the alternation of generations. Previously organisms were haploid, meaning they had one set of genes and that was it. This made them more prone to genetic diseases and if there was a harmful mutation in a vital gene, they would perish. When sexual reproduction appeared, organisms became more resilient because they had two sets of genes and became what is known as diploid. That is why we humans have 46 chromosomes, but we say we have 23 pairs. This allows for interesting mixes in recessives and dominants to allow for more variation and natural selection. The alternation of generations concept is that some organisms live part of their life cycle as haploids and part as diploids. Though we humans only have a short haploid phase as sperm and eggs, some fungi live mostly in a haploid state, while more primitive plants can be half in half living as sporophytes (diploid) or gametophytes (haploid).
contentItems.title: Alternation of Generations

contentItems.description: Though cells have been able to pick up chemical cues since their origins, multicellular life would require much more complex systems. Cells that were vast distances away from one another would need to communicate somehow. The endocrine or hormone system is made up of chemical compounds that travel through the blood or transport fluid of the organism to create a reaction in the cell. They can be protein which are usually faster acting such as adrenaline and lipids which usually induce DNA transcription and have longer term effects like steroids. The nervous system is the much faster acting system which uses ion channels to induce electrical currents through specialized nerve cells to send messages. Plants have complex communication systems as well, using pheromones and hormones to signal. Auxins induce cell growth, cytokinins induce cell division, GAs which promote germination and ethylene which promotes fruit ripening.
contentItems.title: Multicellular Communication

contentItems.description: All multicellular animals have different cell types that have specialized functions within the organism: muscle cells for movement, nerve cells for perception, hormonal glands, digestive cells for nourishment... but they all had to originate from one zygote that came from a sperm and an egg. This one cell divided and specialized into all the different types of cells present in the body, though every cell contains the same genetic information. Every division the cell makes is somewhat unequal, with more of certain proteins and organelles originally present in the zygote on one end than on the other. Based on this, certain genes are turned on or off in the daughter cells, and though the actual DNA is still there, how this DNA is used can be very different. This is the topic of epigenetics, or inheritance that occurs above the level of DNA. Pluripotent stem cells are special because they have the capacity to become any adult cell in the body.
contentItems.title: Cell differentiation and Stem cells

contentItems.description: All higher plants had a common origin in green algae that originated in the ocean. Though they had to evolve substantially before they were recognizable as modern plants, the first steps were made in the ocean. Photosynthesis had been around for quite some time but they were the first plants to become truly multicellular. It is a very diverse group however and there are still single celled members in it, making it more basal than modern plants. One distinguishing feature besides the aquatic nature of algae and lack of a vascular support system is the flagella and mobility of algal cells at some stage, which land plants do not have.
contentItems.title: Algae and higher plants

contentItems.description: Molecular oxygen is made up of two oxygen atoms double bonded together. It comprises about 21% of the atmosphere and it is what allows complex multicellular life to function. The way it does this is by a chemical process known as "Redox" or Reduction-Oxidation. Most elements want to be like Noble Gases (elements in the column of helium), which are non-reactive. This is because this is the lowest energy state they can be in, and is the basis for a concept known as electronegativity. An element is electronegative if it will try to gain electrons and an electropositive one will try to get rid of them. Oxygen is a good oxidizer, meaning it is good at accepting electrons because it is very electronegative. This makes it very reactive and capable of bonding with many different compounds. This makes it good for breaking down complex compounds and harnessing a lot of energy from them, allowing for much more chemistry and biological properties.
contentItems.title: Molecular Oxygen

contentItems.description:
It took over a billion years of evolution for photosynthesis to appear in the first life forms and for enough oxygen to be created to change the atmosphere of the planet. However, when the atmosphere did change, it had an enormous impact on life. 

This rock from early in the history of photosynthesis is rich in iron, and the red portions are oxidized iron (hematite, or Fe2O3) that record the production of oxygen as a byproduct of photosynthesis and its absorption by iron. The red columns are stromatolites, or structures produced by the photosynthetic bacteria that produced the oxygen. The penny shows the scale.
contentItems.title: Banded Iron Formation (BIF)

contentItems.description: Salman Khan explains the process of photosynthesis.
contentItems.title: Photosynthesis

contentItems.description: The first photosynthetic organisms didn't use chloroplasts or chlorophyll, but rather a pigment called phycocyanin that they contained in clusters phycobilisomes. What this pigment does is absorb different wavelengths of red and orange light, while reflecting blue and green ones, giving cyanobacteria their bluish green coloring. They used this absorbed light to red reduce carbon dioxide and oxidize water to produce molecular oxygen and sugars. Since they are water soluble, phycocyanins are stored in protein complexes in the membranes of cells.
contentItems.title: Phycocyanin

contentItems.description: Before photosynthesis appeared organisms carried out lower energy chemical reactions, using like hydrogen sulfide and methane. These were anaerobic reactions, meaning they didn't use oxygen to carry out. Organisms with this kind of chemistry still exist today, deep underground or near hydrothermal vents at the bottom of the ocean. For many in fact oxygen is damaging to them and they are usually known as extremophiles. It wasn't until much later that organisms were able to harness the power of the sun for energy. It is thought the first organisms were similar to modern cyanobacteria, or blue green algae. They are prokaryotic and don't have chloroplasts, only special folds in their membranes where the photosynthetic pigments are concentrated. In fact, modern theories suggest that chloroplasts in plants
contentItems.title: Cyanobacteria: The first photosynthetic organisms

contentItems.description: All life on the surface of the Earth is solar powered in a sense. Granted there are several exceptions to this rule since there are bacteria that exist in the deep places of the earth that form the basis of food chains without the need for sun, through a process called chemiosynthesis. But for the most part, life depends on the Sun for energy. How this works on a molecular level is that plants use photons from the Sun (in the blue and red part of the spectrum, reflecting green back which is what we see) to break the bonds in water and CO2, and form new, higher energy bonds as sugars and they use chlorophyll as a pigment to do this. This sugars can then be broken down to create energy as ATP to power the production of other organic molecules, or used to build cell walls as cellulose, or stored as starch. As animals eat plants and the energy moves up the food chain, these high energy bonds move up as well, meaning we all run on solar power.
contentItems.title: Photosynthesis: Solar Powered Life

contentItems.description: Although the Great Oxygenation event caused a glaciation and mass extinction of many microbial taxa, it did make way for a new kind of chemistry life that would later come to be the dominant kind on earth. Oxygen is a very reactive molecule and can be damaging under the wrong conditions, but if utilized properly, it can be harnessed to produce a great amount of energy. Cells will use oxygen's high reactivity to break down complex molecules into simpler ones, and using the energy that process releases to carry their own cellular functions. The simplest version of this is the breakdown of glucose, the product of photosynthesis. It takes place in 3 steps main steps, the first where the glucose is split in half into two pyruvates. The second, or Krebb's Cycle, is where the pyruvates are broken down and used to produce a lot of NADHs, a carrier molecule. And the final step is Oxidative Phosphorylation, where the most energy is produced in the form of ATP.
contentItems.title: Cellular Respiration and Energy

contentItems.description: The Carbon Cycle is a very important and dynamic process by which elemental carbon cycles through the ecosystem. A variety of traits make it a good element to bond with and to create long polymers such as its ability to make 4 bonds, its ability to make stronger double and triple bonds, hybridized orbitals (where structures are stabilized and can transfer energy through electron resonance), and it's ability to hold positive or negative charges under different conditions depending on the bond needed to be made. This versatility is seen as it transforms through the environment as inorganic gaseous CO2 into organic sugars, fats and amino acids and then back into CO2. It can be subducted under the Earth's crust and then released by volcanoes as gas. It can even be dissolved in the oceans and act as a buffer against pH changes as bicarbonate. Without this cycle, life would go extinct very quickly, since carbon would accumulate in some form or another.
contentItems.title: The Carbon Cycle

contentItems.description: When we talk about carbohydrates, lipids or proteins as being sources of energy we are being somewhat misleading. Though we do acquire energy when we consume them and we need them to survive, the actual source of energy for our bodies is a molecule called Adenosine Triphosphate, abbreviated as ATP. It is the universal molecule that cells use as an energy source to carry out its functions. What make's ATP so energetically charged is the fact that it has three very negatively charged phosphate groups bound very closely to one another. This repelling force held so closely together allows ATP to transmit it's energy to other systems by "phosphorylating" them. Essentially what this means is that some of that stored energy can be passed on to another system (such as an enzyme) by giving one of it's phosphate groups to it. To restore itself to ATP it needs to break down a complex molecule, continuing the cycle.
contentItems.title: ATP: The Energy Currency of Cells

contentItems.description: Though calling this event a catastrophe may be a misnomer since life as we know it would not be able to exist without this event, it did cause a shift in worldwide biota and likely a mass extinction at a microbial level. Once oxygen producing organisms arose, many changes occurred to the physical environment. Oxygen caused a great amount of rusting of iron, leaving large formations. Once most iron on earth was rusted, the oxygen would have started to accumulate in the atmosphere, creating the ozone layer, an unstable form of three oxygen atoms bonded together, shielding life from harmful UV rays. However, not all the changes were good, the corrosive nature of oxygen meant that a lot of organisms were either damaged by it or the chemicals they utilized for metabolism disappeared or were confined to niche extreme environments. It also oxidize methane, a greenhouse gas, leaving Earth fell into a large ice age known as the “Snowball Earth” period
contentItems.title: The Oxygen Catastrophe

contentItems.description: Carbon may be the backbone of life, water its solvent but there a lot more elements required to to make complex biomolecules. Nitrogen is another versatile element that is more abundant in our atmosphere than oxygen. It is a necessity for life because it is required to produce amino acids which make up proteins in our bodies. These proteins carry out every function in the cell from metabolism, to reproduction to movement. Without nitrogen we would not be able to produce these proteins, and that is why it is such an important nutrient in agriculture. Like carbon, it also cycles through the environment with ease, going from gaseous molecular nitrogen (N2), to liquid ammonia, to solid nitrates. About 96% of our mass comes from carbon, oxygen, hydrogen and nitrogen but many other elements are essential for life such as calcium and sodium and other ions for signaling and enzymatic reactions and phosphorous for DNA.
