contentItems.description: Most members of the Austro-Hungarian elite wanted to react to the assassination with swift action.  They saw themselves the victims of an act of state-sponsored terrorism from a Serbian government that had long been a problem for them.  Many, like General Franz Conrad von Hötzendorff, saw the assassination as the pretext for crippling Serbian power.
contentItems.title: Austria-Hungary

contentItems.description: With war increasingly a possibility, the great powers began to get ready.  At this stage they were still mostly thinking of a local Balkan war, not a wider continental war.  Still, they saw a duty to protect themselves and be ready for anything that might happen.  By late July, however, more and more people saw how the circumstances of 1914 might turn a small diplomatic crisis into the largest war the world had yet known.
contentItems.title: War?

contentItems.description: Germany dispatched the lightly-armed ship Panther to Morocco to support the Sultan.  Although it was a small and inoffensive ship, many people in France and England thought it was an unnecessary German provocation.  Still, neither country thought it important enough to send their own ships to Morocco in response.
contentItems.title: The Panther

contentItems.description: The second crisis began in 1911 after the French Army used too much force in putting down strikes in Moroccan cities.  The Germans again rose to Morocco’s defense and argued that France violated the Algeciras agreement by sending in troops.  French nationalists argued that they were bringing civilization to the Moroccans and that Germany had no business interfering.
contentItems.title: July, 1911

contentItems.description: The saying "Time is Money" is often attributed to Benjamin Franklin. In 1748, Franklin wrote "Advice to a Young Tradesman," which recommended that one should “remember that time is money.” Franklin described the meaning of this proverb by comparing a man's earnings for an entire day's work to the earnings of a man who idles half the day. “Though he spends but sixpence during his diversion or idleness,” Franklin explained, “he has really spent, or rather thrown away, five shillings besides.” Because one can earn wages from an hour's work, an hour wasted is the equivalent of losing those same wages in addition to the money that was spent during such leisure time.
contentItems.title: Benjamin Franklin: "Time is Money"

exhibits.title: "Advice to a Young Tradesman" by Benjamin Franklin

contentItems.description: Christiaan Huygens first made a pendulum clock in 1657. His invention is widely cited as the beginning of the Horological Revolution. The pendulum clock, and the other innovations that accompanied it thereafter, allowed for the production of clocks that were cheaper and more accurate. For the first time, people outside the aristocracy and royalty could afford to own clocks and even more importantly pocket watches, which allowed for personalized timekeeping. Prior to Huygens, clocks could not be relied on for accuracy beyond an expected error of 15 minutes per day. The pendulum helped reduce that margin of error to about 10-15 seconds.
contentItems.title: Christiaan Huygens

contentItems.description: “[T]he public clocks of the city of Edinburgh were altered from their actual time by command of the town council” and in this way “the clocks were made to lie” by ceasing to be “regulated by the sun.” This editorial from Blackwood's Edinburgh Magazine confronted time reform with a religious intensity, declaring that “we shall not get up a single second sooner than we ought to do.” The difference of twelve and half minutes between local Edinburgh time and Greenwich Mean Time was less important than the “arbitrary power” the time adjustment represented, “defrauding” men of extra minutes in bed by way of a “foul conspiracy.”
contentItems.title: Blackwood's Protests Greenwich Mean Time

contentItems.description: In the story “Oliver Fearnleaf's Watch,” the so-called ‘poet of Lancashire,’ Edwin Waugh, wrote about a man who lives more freely without a pocket watch. The character of Oliver Fearnleaf could “see many compensations arising from the absence of a watch” given that the “sights, shapes and sounds” could be his time markers “and the whole world was [his] clock.” Waugh imagined Fearnleaf finding that his watch had swallowed up “a good deal of pocket money” in maintenance costs. The watch became “a continual source of anxiety” and so Fearnleaf got rid of it. This suggests an attitude towards timekeeping that may not have been obvious to those writing about an apparently self-evident need for time reform. Waugh does ascribe one significant inconvenience to lacking an accurate watch: Oliver Fearnleaf always misses the train...
contentItems.title: Edwin Waugh - "The Poet of Lancashire"

contentItems.description: Ruth Belville, a woman known to Britons as the “Greenwich Time Lady,” spent her life working in the following unique profession: in the morning, she would visit the Royal Observatory at Greenwich and set her pocket watch to exact Greenwich Mean Time and then for the rest of the day she visited her customers who paid her for the right to look at her watch and set their clocks by it. She had inherited the job from her mother, Maria Belville (pictured above), who in turn received the position at the time of her own husband's death. Maria's husband, John Henry Belville, started the business by virtue of working in the Royal Observatory during the midcentury period when Greenwich Mean Time first gained national prominence.
contentItems.title: The Greenwich Time Lady

contentItems.description: By the early 20th century, anxious Britons sent frustrated letters to The Times of London decrying the 'lying clocks' that still failed to adopt consistent Greenwich Mean Time reckoning. These letters strongly supported a more modern timekeeping system. In their view, the failure to effectively establish such a system was an embarrassing contrast to the efficient and accurate timekeeping systems used by Paris, Berlin, Brussels, Vienna and elsewhere.
contentItems.title: January 10, 1908

contentItems.description: “Men of business are accustomed to quote the maxim that Time is money,” wrote Samuel Smiles in 1859, setting up a clear contrast between men of business and men of idleness who would allow “an hour wasted daily on trifles or in indolence.” Samuel Smiles’ books were extremely popular, and scholars have argued no one is more representative of the Victorian Era than him. Smiles' most famous work, Self-Help, represents a great many beliefs at the heart of British cultural identity. This identity included a belief in the phrase "time is money." Smiles advised that time should be “employed in good works.” If hours of indolence were put to proper use, they would “make an ignorant man wise in a few years.”
contentItems.title: Samuel Smiles: "Time is Money"

contentItems.description: A Tzompantli, or skull rack, is a type of wooden palisade that was used to display sacrificed human skulls by the ancient Mesoamericans. Seen here is the altar where the heads of the captives were sacrificed to honor the gods. The Tzompantli was most commonly erected as a linearly-arranged series of vertical posts connected by a series of horizontal crossbeams. The skulls were pierced or threaded laterally along these horizontal stakes. More common in the Maya regions, an alternate arrangement was for the skulls to be impaled on top of one another along the vertical posts.
contentItems.title: Altar

contentItems.description: The Spanish conquest of the Yucatan was the campaign undertaken by the Spanish "conquistadores" against the Late Post Classic Maya states. The campaign began in the early 16th century but would take about 170 years until the last recognized Maya stronghold fell. One of the first contacts was in 1517 when Hernández de Córdoba sailed from Cuba in search of slaves. The Spaniards were surprised to see stone cities along the coast of the Yucatan and landed in several different cities. After Spanish dominion over the region was established the Maya people remained resistant under Spanish rule.
contentItems.title: The Spanish Arrive at the Yucatán under Francisco Hernández de Córdoba

exhibits.title: The Spanish Conquest of the Yucatán

contentItems.description: Tulum has architecture typical of Maya sites on the east coast of the Yucatan Peninsula, recognized by a step running around the base of the building which sits on a low substructure. Until the early twentieth century, some villages used to visit the site to bring gifts but the steady stream of tourists made the practice obsolete. Some frescoes found inside buildings suggest some Mixtec influence in the community.
contentItems.title: Architecture of Tulum

contentItems.description: Tulum or Tuluum Tulum was a walled city of the Mayan culture located in the State of Quintana Roo in southeastern Mexico on the Caribbean coast. Tulum was at its height between the 13th and 15th centuries. Having managed to survive about 70 years after the Spanish occupation of Mexico, it is believed that Old World diseases brought by Spanish settlers caused its demise.
contentItems.title: Tulum - The Walled City

contentItems.description: Tulum is the site of a Pre-Columbian Maya walled city that serves as a major port for Coba. Along the east coast of the Yucatan Peninsula on the Caribbean Sea in the state of Quintana Roo, Mexico, Tulum was one of the last cities inhabited and built by Mayans. For the many records in murals and other works found in the buildings of the city, it is believed that Tulum was an important center of worship for the "god descending".
contentItems.title: The City of Tulum

contentItems.description: The city received the name in ancient Maya Zama (meaning dawn in Mayan) and the current, Tulum (meaning wall in Maya), which seems to have been used to refer to the city when it was already in ruins. Having access to both land and sea trade routes, Tulum was made an important trade hub, especially for obsidian. Tulum had an estimated population of 1,000 to 1,600 inhabitants.
contentItems.title: Zama

contentItems.description: Tulum was first mentioned by Juan Diaz, a member of Juan de Grijalva's 1518 Spanish expedition. John Lloyd Stephens and Frederick Catherwood made the first detailed description of the ruins in 1843. Archaeologist Pilar Luna, a specialist in marine archeology in Mexico, explains that the importance of the building known as "The Castle" for Mayan sailors, was it allowed them to avoid the dangers of the second longest coral reef in the world.
contentItems.title: "The Castle"

contentItems.description: This tiny temple is located on the eastern side of the street and is the most richly ornamented in carvings and in paintings. Originally the structure was a one room building with a small altar attached to the wall. Temple of Frescoes dates back to the mid 1400s, and is a two-story building with colorful murals on the inner wall. It is thought to have been one of the last structures built by the Maya before the arrival of Hernan Cortez.
contentItems.title: Templo de Los Frescos

contentItems.description: This is one of the most important buildings in the holy city of the Itzáes. "The Snail" is located to the North of Las Monjas. A round building on a large square platform, El Caracol gets its name from the stone spiral staircase inside. The structure, with its unusual placement on the platform, is theorized to be a proto-observatory.
contentItems.title: El Caracol

contentItems.description: At some distance of the large platform are the remains of some small buildings, including a steam bath and a round tub built into the floor, which contains several steps and filled with water through a pipe. The doors and windows of El Caracol are aligned to astronomical events, specifically around the path of Venus as it traverses the heavens.
contentItems.title: Building footprints

contentItems.description: Some researchers found that the walls of the observation chamber had small slits visually oriented towards the four cardinal points. El Caracol may be an ancient Maya observatory building that served as a man-made marker, and provided a way for the Maya people to observe changes in the sky. Due to the flattened landscape of the Yucatán with no natural markers for this function around Chichen Itza, with the observatory one could view the sky above the vegetation on the Yucatán Peninsula without any obstruction.
contentItems.title: Four Cardinal Points

contentItems.description: Mayapan is a Pre-Columbian Maya site in the state of Yucatan, Mexico. It was the political and cultural capital of the Maya during the Late Post-Classic period from the 1220s until the 1440s. Carnegie archaeologist A.L. Smith estimated 10-12,000 people lived within the walled parameter. People who lived outside of the city wall engaged in agriculture, animal raising, and specialized activities.
contentItems.title: Mayan ruins in Mayapan

exhibits.title: Mayapan became the capital of Maya

contentItems.description: Halach Uinik (Mayan: Halach Uinik, "Man in fact Man of control") was the name given to maximum ruler, leader of a Mayan jurisdiction. The highest ranking person in each city was called the Halach Unic. The three main classes in Mayan society were royalty, wealthy, and poor. The royalty lived in palaces and led the Mayan empire. The wealthy lived in large houses around the palace to signify their wealth. The poor lived along the outskirts of towns in small huts and worked all day as slaves.
contentItems.title: Halach Unic

contentItems.description: One of the more notable buildings of the Chichen Itza, Las Monjas is a complex of Terminal Classic buildings constructed in the Puuc architectural style. This building is considered a residential palace, but there are divided opinions among scholars. Some think that was the residence of the family that founded Chichen Itza or the government house or the high priest house.
contentItems.title: "La Iglesia" in the Las Monjas complex

contentItems.description: It has a Puuc construction style, to which the Spanish called La Casa de las Monjas because it´s like a convent with a large number of rooms. Las Monjas means "nuns," but the place is actually intended as a governmental palace. The Las Monjas group is distinguished by hieroglyphic texts dating to the Late to Terminal Classic, that frequently mention a ruler by the name of Kakupakal.
contentItems.title: La Casa de las Monjas

contentItems.description: This construction worshiped the god Kukulkan (Mayan language: Feathered Serpent), which is why you can see serpentine motifs in the architectural decoration. Kukulkan is the name of a Mayan snake diety. Although heavily Mexicanized, Kulkulkan has his origins among the Maya of the Classic Period, when he was known as Waxaklahun Ubah Kan, the War Serpent, and he has been identified as the Postclassic version of the Vision Serpent of Classic Maya art.
contentItems.title: Pyramid of Kukulkan

contentItems.description: The alignment of the pyramid construction allows it to observe various phenomena of light and shadow, which occur in his own body during the equinoxes and solstices each year.
contentItems.title: Alignment of the pyramid

contentItems.description: In 1988, the Organization of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), declared the Mayan city of Chichen Itza as a World Heritage Site.
contentItems.title: World Heritage Site

contentItems.description: Mayan World markets were established for all people, offering among other things, products made from natural materials such as coconut, seeds, thorns, bones and sculpted and carved gourds. The luxury items such as pens, necklaces, and jade were exclusive to members of the elite. Open markets challenge the idea of a centralized food distribution system where foodstuffs were controlled by the ruling class, gathered in the form of tax and tribute and redistributed according to a complex set of social rules. Instead, market places imply that a free-market economy might have supplemented or co-existed with the tax and tribute system.
contentItems.title: Mayan World Markets

contentItems.description: Cancuen is an archaeological site of the pre-Columbian Maya civilization, located in the present-day Guatemalan Department of El Peten. The city is notable for having one of the largest palaces in the Maya world. During the Classic Period, Cancuen was a major city, reaching its peak during the 7th century. Tajal Chan Ahk, one of Cancuen's most powerful rulers built the city's palace in 770 AD.
contentItems.title: Cancuen Panel

exhibits.title: Tajal Chan Ahk built palace at Cancuen

contentItems.description: The ball game was played in a large masonry structure. Constructed in a way that did not change much for 2700 years, over 1300 golf ball games in Mesoamerica have been identified, 60% of these only in the last 20 years. Archaeologists have identified thirteen ballcourts for playing the Mesoamerican ballgame in Chichen Itza, but the Great Ball Court is by far the largest and best preserved ball court in ancient Mesoamerica.
contentItems.title: Stone Ballcourt Goal

contentItems.description: The Mesoamerica ballgame in Nahuatl was a sport with ritual associations played since 1,400 BC by pre-Columbian people. A modern version of the sport, ulama, is still played in a few places by the local indigenous population. The rules of the ballgame seem similar to racquetball, where the object of the game is to keep the ball in play.
contentItems.title: Mesoamerica ballgame in Nahuatl

contentItems.description: The Mayan myth of the Twins of the Popol Vuh states the importance of the game as a symbol of the war closely related to the theme of fertility. Called Hunahpu and Xbalanque in Quiche, the Twins could be considered as mythical ancestors to the Mayan ruling lineages. The game between Hunahpu, Xbalanque and the Xibalbans ultimately resulted in an embarrasing defeat for the Xibalbans.
contentItems.title: Twins of the Popol Vuh

contentItems.description: The ballgame field becomes a place of transition, a liminal stage between life and death.
contentItems.title: Chichen Itza Ball Court, Cancun, Mexico

contentItems.description: This example of Maya writing is on display in the Museo de sitio in Palenque, a former Maya city state in southern Mexico. The Maya script was a logosyllabic system. Individual symbols, or glyphs, could represent either words or syllables. Ambiguity was common in Maya. Sometimes, the same glyph could be used for both a word or a vowel. In contrast, there are also many examples of different glyphs that can be read the same way. For example, the very common Mayan third-person pronoun u- was represented by at least half a dozen seemingly disparate glyphs.
contentItems.title: Palenque glyphs

contentItems.description: Maya writing, which consisted of intricate symbolic glyphs, was most commonly organized into columns two glyphs wide. As diagrammed above, reading and writing proceeded from left to right and down a column, with the bottom-right glyph of a column joining with the top-left glyph of the next column. Within each individual block, glyph elements were arranged top to bottom and left to right, with each block usually representing a noun or verb phrase.
contentItems.title: Maya writing order

contentItems.description: The Mayans utilized a positional base-twenty numerical system that only contained whole numbers. Visually, a shell represented zero, while a dot and a bar represented 1 and 5, respectively. Numerals using combinations of these existed from 0 to 19. To count to greater figures, base-twenty place values were assembled vertically. Thus, the bottom position representing multiples of 1, the next position above it multiples of 20, then multiples of 400, 8000, etc. This figure illustrates how to calculate larger Mayan numerals from their visual representation.
contentItems.title: Mayan numerical system

contentItems.description: The Maya script is the writing system of the Maya civilization. Maya writing used logograms complemented by a set of syllabic glyphs, somewhat similar to modern Japanese writing. Mayan writing has received official support and promotion by the Mexican government and is taught in universities and public schools in some Mayan speaking areas.
contentItems.title: Mayan Glyphs, Palenque, Mexico

contentItems.description: Tikal, a city of the Mayan civilization, reached its height during the Classical Period. During this time, the city dominated much of the Maya region politically, economically, and militarily while interacting with other areas such as Teotihuancán. One of the most studied sites is the North Acropolis. The North Acropolis (pictured here) developed into a funerary complex for the ruling dynasty of the Classic Period. Each additional royal burial added new temples and pyramids on top of the existing structure. The North Acropolis continued to receive burials into the Postclassic Period. It is located in present day Guatemala; the site is part of Guatemala's Tikal National Park.
contentItems.title: Tikal

exhibits.title: Tikal Becomes the Center of the Mayan Civilization

contentItems.description: The Jaguar Temple dates back to 625AD. It is named for its boxy jaguar decoration. The most interesting features of the temple are two masks at the west facade. The masks are human faces surrounded by decorative elements. The headdresses of the masks are representations of crocodiles. Lamanai, Belize is home to sizable Mayan ruins that used to be the ancient city of Lamanai meaning submerged crocodile. The name was a reference to the reptiles that lived along the bank of the New River. There is evidence that Mayan life here dates back to the Pre-classic period all the way through the Spanish Colonial period.
contentItems.title: The Jaguar Temple

contentItems.description: The Spanish conquest of Yucatan was the campaign undertaken by the Spanish conquistadores against the Late Postclassic Maya states and polities. The episode of conquest and colonization of the Americas began in the early 16th century, but was more difficult and lengthy than the conquest of the Aztecs and Incas. The last recognized Maya stronghold fell, at the Itza capital of Tayasal, in 1697.
contentItems.title: Yucatan Conquest

exhibits.title: Falling of the last recognized Maya stronghold

contentItems.description: The Mayan writing system was developed around 300 BCE and continuously used until the arrival of the Spanish in the 16th century. The writing system is considered one of the most visually striking writing systems in the world. It is very complex, with hundreds of unique signs in the forms of humans, animals, objects, and abstract design. These signs are either logograms used to express meaning or syllabograms used to denote sound. This is an example of Mayan glyphs carved into stucco displayed at a museum in Palenque, Mexico.
contentItems.title: The Mayan Writing System

contentItems.description: Kaminaljuyu is a Pre-Columbian site of the Maya civilization that was primarily occupied from 1500 BC to AD 1200. It has been described as one of the greatest of all archaeological sites in the New World, although its remains today are far less impressive. It was comprised of some 200 platforms and pyramidal mounds, half of which were created before the end of the Preclassic period.
contentItems.title: Monument 65, Kaminaljuyu, Guatemala

contentItems.description: Teotihuancán was an ancient Mayan city founded around 100 BCE that continued to be built until 250 CE. For hundreds of years the city was the cultural, religious, and trading center of the Mayan Civilization. The city is thought to have lasted until the 7th and 8th centuries. The city began to come to an end in 869 and was fully abandoned in 899. The largest pyramid, the Pyramid of the Sun, was completed by 100AD. Today, the city is considered an archaeological site that contains the largest pyramidal structures built in the pre-columbian Americas.
contentItems.title: View From The Pyramid of the Sun at Teotihuancán

contentItems.description: An archaeologist with help from the National Geographic Society discovers a never-before-seen Maya calendar in Guatemala that may dispel the myth predicting end times in 2012. It's the first glimpse of what science was like before the arrival of the Spanish, at the height of the Mayan civilization. Evidence was provided that even the Mayan themselves were not hemmed in by such a finite conception of time.
contentItems.title: Video: Doomsday Delayed? New Maya Calendar Unearthed

contentItems.description: Haab' is name given to the Maya version of the 365-day calendar, which was common to many Pre-Columbian Mesoamerica cultures. Approximating the solar year, the Haab' was divided into 18 months of 20 days each and culminated with an additional five 'nameless' days, known as Wayeb'. Estimated to have been first used around 500 BCE, the Haab' created the basis for the Mayan agrarian cycle, and the months were based on the seasons and agricultural or climatological phenomena. Pictured above is a glyph representing Pax , the 16th month of Haab'. Pax and its glyph are associated with the time for planting crops.
contentItems.title: Haab'

contentItems.description: This video provides a helpful visual representation explaining the Mayan calendar and its various counts. The calendar round is made up of three interlocking cycles, a 365 day solar year, a cycle of 20 names, and  a cycle of 30 numbers. Days are designated by the way these three cycles line up. 52 years will pass before the same 3 cycles line up again.
contentItems.title: Explaining the Maya Calendar

contentItems.description: December 21, 2012, marks the end of a b'ak'tun, a period of 5,125 years based on the hierarchical modified base-twenty counting system of the Maya Long Count calendar. Some people and groups have interpreted this day to be associated with transformative, or possibly cataclysmic events, ranging from the start of a new era to the coming of the Apocalypse. Scholars have generally dismissed these interpretations as misguided, citing lack of evidence in recorded Mayan history for this date being significant at all other than marking the end of a relatively long cycle.
contentItems.title: Did the Mayans predict the end of the world?

contentItems.description: "Tzolk'in" is the name given to the Maya 260-day calendar, also known as the Sacred Round. This is a ritual calendar, with no apparent correspondence to astronomical or agricultural cycles. The Tzolk'in combines a cycle of 20 named days with another count of thirteen numbers, producing 260 unique days. Each named day is associated with a natural object or phenomena. The Mayan glyph for "Imix", the first named day of the Tzolk'in calendar, is shown above. Imix is associated with the Crocodile, representing the "reptilian body" of the Earth.
contentItems.title: Tzolk'in

contentItems.attribution: Cyrus Thomas (1904) Mayan calendar Systems II
contentItems.description: When combined, the 260-day Tzolk'in count and the 365-day Haab' count produce a 18980-day (52 Haab') cycle known as a Calendar Round. However, to keep track of periods of time longer than 52 solar years, the Maya used the Long Count system. The Long Count calendar uses a modified base-twenty counting system to identify and record days elapsed since the Mayan creation date of 4 Ahaw, 8 Kumk'u (the equivalent of August 11, 3114 BCE on the Gregorian calendar). The image above ilustrates glyphs representing the Mayan creation date, found at the Quiriguá Mayan archaeological site in Guatemala.
contentItems.title: Long Count

contentItems.description: The Maya calendar dates back to at least the 5th century BCE, and is perhaps the most-studied and best-understood calendar of the early Mesoamerican civilizations. Like other related Mesoamerican calendars, such as the Aztec and Zapotec, the Maya calendar consists of several cycles, or counts, of varying lengths. The 260-day count, known as "Tzolk'in" in Maya, was common to all Mesoamerican calendars. This was combined with the "Haab", a 365-day count based on the solar year. These two counts combined to form the Calendar Round, a synchronized cycle that lasted for 52 solar years.
contentItems.title: Maya Calendar

timeline.title: French Wars and Loss of American Colonies
Second Union of Aragon and Navarre
First Union of Aragon and Navarre

contentItems.attribution: George Bird Grinnell and Marcus Benjamin
contentItems.description: During the late 1800's, North America saw an explosion of new discoveries of dinosaurs, some of which are the most well known and complete specimens to date. This was largely due to two people, Othniel Charles Marsh and Edward Drinker Cope. They were both wealthy men who used their wealth to finance expeditions into the midwest. Between the two of them, over 130 new dinosaur species were discovered and named. This intense competition between the two often led to them destroying each other's finds and using underhanded means to gain an advantage over the other.
contentItems.title: Bone Wars

contentItems.description: Though both men humiliated each other and were ruined from this feud, they left a lasting legacy. Between the two of them over 130 new species had been identified, some of which became the most well known species to date such as Triceratops, Stegosaurus and Allosaurus. Some of their ideas stood the test of time, such as Marsh's claim that birds are the descendants of dinosaurs. They also increased public awareness of dinosaurs and captured the public's imagination by bringing attention to the extinct creatures.
contentItems.title: Legacy

contentItems.description: At times the confrontations became so bad that both men needed armed soldiers for protection and to protect their finds. Both men attempted to sabotage one another several times, publicly tried to discredit and humiliate each other and even steal or destroy each other's finds. Dynamite was even used by Cope to cover up a quarry that was no longer being used, just to make sure Marsh would not find anything he left behind.
contentItems.title: Ugly Confrontations

contentItems.description: Both scientists made their fair share of mistakes. In his haste Cope put the head of Elasmosaurus, a marine reptile distantly related to dinosaurs, on the tail of the creature, thinking that the longer side of the vertebrae would have served as the propulsion mechanism for this creature. However, the neck on elasmosaurus was actually longer, as it used it to catch fish, and actually used its fins for propulsion, somewhat like a sea turtle. Marsh was sure to make this mistake evident to the public and humiliated Cope deliberately, but he was not infallible himself. He placed a wrong skull on an apatosaurus skeleton and declared it a new species: Brontosaurus.
contentItems.title: Mistakes

contentItems.description: The term Dinosaur was first coined by Sir Richard Owen in 1942 to describe a group of large extinct reptiles that were being discovered around the world. The word itself means 'terrible lizards' and was chosen because of the awe inspired by the size of these grandiose creatures.
contentItems.title: Sir Richard Owen

contentItems.description: Iguanodon was a medium to large herbivore by dinosaur standards, that existed in the early cretaceous. It is classified as an ornithopod because of its bird-like hips and it had a distinctive thumb spike that would have allowed it to reach tall branches or defend itself from predators. It was a puzzling find for Mantell who did not immediately know what to make of such large bones and teeth but ultimately gave it the name Iguanodon because the teeth were similar to those of a very large iguana. However the final appearance of this and many other dinosaurs evolved over time as our understanding of dinosaurs improved.
contentItems.title: Iguanodon

contentItems.description: Here is a picture of a more complete Iguanodon reconstruction. Here the thumb spike is accurately placed on the hand, and not the nose.
contentItems.title: Old Reconstruction

contentItems.description: Dinosaurs have fascinated Man for many years and captured the imaginations of millions during that time. Although we have only known dinosaurs as such for around two hundred years, stories of dragons and monsters created to explain their fossilized bones have been around for thousands of years. Dinosaurs have played an important role in the understanding our world in many ways, and their discovery has a history that is almost as interesting as the natural history of dinosaurs themselves.
contentItems.title: History of Dinosaurs

contentItems.description: The first artistic renditions of Iguanodon depicted it as a huge lumbering monster that looked nothing like it does today. It had a much more fearsome appearance and the thumb spike was placed on it's nose like a rhinoceros. Many of these mistakes were because of incomplete fossil evidence but there were also anatomical mistakes because of limited knowledge about animals at the time and because this image fit nicely with our assumptions about dinosaurs as monstrous creatures from a bygone era.
contentItems.title: First Dinosaur Images

contentItems.description: The image of Iguanodon changed a lot over time but now we feel we have a fairly good understanding of what it must have looked like, behaved like and even eaten because of fossilized feces, footprints, nests and even skin imprints. Iguanodon was likely a highly active grazing animal much like today's grazers that would have been warm blooded and capable of running on two legs if in danger. However, most of the time it would have spent its life on all fours, with a rigid tail it used for balance. It also most likely traveled in herds where it would have found safety in numbers.
contentItems.title: Final Understanding

contentItems.description: The first dinosaur to be discovered and acknowledged as a large extinct species of reptile was discovered by a paleontologist by the name of Gideon Mantell. Initially only consisting of a few teeth, and later being completed with more bones, the dinosaur he discovered was named Iguanodon, for it's iguana-shaped teeth.
contentItems.title: Gideon Mantell

contentItems.description: Mantell's very first restoration of Iguanodon depicted it based off of very incomplete evidence and looking like an Iguana perched on a tree with a long lizard-like tail. Notice many important parts of the body are missing such as the skull and tail, which would have helped improve the accuracy of this picture.
contentItems.title: Mantell's Notes

contentItems.description: It took some time for paleontologists to discover enough of Iguanodon to make an accurate portrayal of how all of the bones fit together. However certain aspects of its physiology and biology needed to be altered further. It still dragged its tail in most depictions and had a very lizard-like appearance to it. It was also shown as living near swamps and still had a somewhat lumbering feel to it. However, this was a good next step in our understanding of dinosaurs.
contentItems.title: Subsequent Restorations

contentItems.attribution: Scan from The Illustrated Encyclopaedia of Dinosaurs
contentItems.description: The discovery of Iguanodon got Mantell so excited that he hosted a dinner party inside of an inaccurate reconstruction of the creature. These statues still stand in Crystal Palace Park in England.
contentItems.title: Crystal Palace Dinner

contentItems.description: Over the years, more and more discoveries of dinosaurs with feathers have been made. Most of these would have been closely related to birds and would have been in the raptor family, but increasingly it is being suggested that many other kinds of dinosaurs may have in fact had downy plumage. Especially in juvenile dinosaurs, it is thought the feathers would have kept the young warm, and in larger dinosaurs it would have fallen out. Microraptor is one discovery of a small raptor that would have acted much like a carnivorous flying squirrel, gliding from tree to tree, feeding on small prey.
contentItems.title: Microraptor

contentItems.description: Bob Bakker was a major proponent of dinosaurs being warm blooded, smart and agile during a time when the established view was quite the opposite. He uncovered evidence about dinosaur nesting and was a strong supporter of the theory that birds evolved from dinosaurs.
contentItems.title: Bob Bakker

contentItems.description: When Jack Horner discovered hundreds of nests full of eggs and baby dinosaurs in them, and specimens of all ages around the area, he concluded that dinosaurs could in fact be good parents and actually raise their offspring. He even named the dinosaur Maiasaura, which means "Good Mother Lizard."
contentItems.title: Good Mothers

contentItems.description: Maiasaura was a large Hadrosaur, a herbivorous dinosaur that lived during the Cretaceous period. It lived in North America and was likely the prey of Tyrannosaurs. It's complex nesting behavior meant that dinosaurs were likely not the lumbering monsters they were traditionally depicted to be, but actually intelligent and highly adaptive creatures that acted in ways we would be familiar with ourselves.
contentItems.title: Maiasaura

contentItems.description: Recent finds have shown that many dinosaurs had feathers or even wings that they may have used for display, warmth or even gliding. There are many anatomical similarities between certain small carnivorous dinosaurs and birds such as arm and hand structure.
contentItems.title: Feathers

contentItems.description: Jack Horner was one of the leading paleontologists during the Dinosaur Renaissance. He held the then unpopular position that dinosaurs must have evolved into birds. Now with many new finds, it is well established that birds are dinosaur's direct descendants. He also was a scientific advisor for the Jurassic Park movies.
contentItems.title: Jack Horner

contentItems.description: When first proposed, the idea of dinosaurs being related to birds seemed preposterous. After all, they were huge terrifying lizards that only had a thirst for blood. However, over the years as our understanding of dinosaurs grew, comparative anatomy between birds and dinosaurs improved, and more discoveries showed a closer and closer link between the two groups. It has become common knowledge that birds must have arisen from dinosaurs. With current genetic engineering, it has been shown possible to grow tails and teeth in chickens. The ancestral traits of dinosaurs have also been found within their DNA. However, some still scoff at the idea of a chickenosaurus.
contentItems.title: Chickenosaurus

contentItems.description: Many depictions of dragons have remarkable similarities to theropod dinosaurs being depicted as bipedal and carnivorous.
contentItems.title: Similarities

contentItems.description: In Judeo-Christian culture, Noah built a huge ark to house two of every animal on earth and shelter them from a massive flood that covered the earth. When bones of extinct dinosaurs were discovered people thought they were the remains of animals that were too large to fit on the ark, and thus perished.
contentItems.title: Too Big for the Ark

contentItems.description: For many centuries people have known about the remains of dinosaurs, through discoveries of their bones and other left overs. There was even a case where a shepherd had built an entire house out of the fossils! But people did not have a good explanation for the existence of these bones. Where were the creatures that left them? Such huge animals would have been an obvious presence. East Asian cultures used the explanation of dragons, European cultures reasoned they were wiped out by the great flood and did not make it onto Noah's ark, and it's possible that the Aztec's god Quetzalcoatl was originally thought of to explain these mysterious findings.
contentItems.title: Dragons or Dinosaurs?

contentItems.description: In many cultures, dragons play a significant role in society or the belief systems. It is interesting to think about how they would have been different had dinosaurs never existed or their bones never found.
contentItems.title: Dragons in our Culture

contentItems.description: Grandi Magazzini di Settimio Severo, showing the different rooms opening southwards onto an internal courtyard
contentItems.title: Grandi Magazzini di Settimio Severo

contentItems.attribution: Click here to view full screen
contentItems.description: Gigapan image of one of the cistern walls
contentItems.title: Gigapan of the Cistern

contentItems.description: The cistern complex at Portus
contentItems.title: The Cistern Complex

contentItems.description: Plan of the cistern at Portus
contentItems.title: Inside the Cistern

contentItems.description: Visual reconstruction of the front façade of the Imperial Palace (Grant Cox, ACRG).
contentItems.title: Imperial Palace visual reconstruction

contentItems.description: The Palazzo Imperiale was a brick- and reticulate-faced concrete structure which covered nearly three hectares. Of its original three storeys, only the substructures and some of the first floor remain. The Palazzo‘s trapezoidal plan was dictated by the spur of land between the two basins on which it was situated.
contentItems.title: Imperial Palace

contentItems.description: Plan showing Trajanic phase
contentItems.title: Trajanic Phase

contentItems.description: Sestertius of Trajan (RIC II, no. 471) minted in AD 112-114 showing the hexagonal harbour on the reverse.
contentItems.title: Coin commemorated by Trajan

contentItems.description: Beginning in c. AD 110, Portus was expanded by the emperor Trajan (Pliny the Younger, Panegyricus XXIX.2). A new hexagonal harbour basin was excavated inland behind the Claudian basin and associated infrastructure was constructed around it including warehouses, a possible ship shed, a temple and an expansive and lavishly decorated administrative building which was later dubbed the Palazzo Imperiale. At least one canal, mentioned by Pliny (Epistulae VIII.17.1-2) and possibly also referred to in a fragmentary inscription (CIL XIV 88 = CIL VI 964), was created by Trajan as well. The inauguration of Trajan’s work at Portus was commemorated with a coin issue displaying a bird’s eye view of the hexagonal harbour on the reverse.
contentItems.title: Inauguration of the Enlargement of Portus by Trajan - Commemorated by a Special Coin Issue Showing the New Hexagonal Basin

exhibits.title: Inauguration of the Enlargement of Portus by Trajan

contentItems.description: Careful excavation of the latrine within the Imperial Palace
contentItems.title: Excavating the latrine

contentItems.description: Fully excavated latrine showing evidence for the marble flooring and expensive fittings
contentItems.title: Excavated latrine

contentItems.description: Computer reconstruction of the latrine within the Imperial Palace
contentItems.title: Visual reconstruction of the latrine

contentItems.description: Aerial photograph of the remains of the amphitheatre shaped building.
contentItems.title: Aerial view of Amphitheatre

contentItems.description: Ground Penetrating Radar results for the Amphitheatre at Portus. Animation by Gareth Beale (Archaeological Computing Research group, University of Southampton)
contentItems.title: Amphitheatre GPR

contentItems.description: Visual reconstruction of the amphitheatre-shaped structure (exterior view)
contentItems.title: Computer reconstruction

contentItems.description: Simon Keay discussing the amphitheatre shaped building
contentItems.title: The Amphitheatre

contentItems.description: Visualisation of the small lighthouse near to the baths at Portus. Animation by Gareth Beale (Archaeological Computing Research group, University of Southampton)
contentItems.title: Small Lighthouse at Portus

contentItems.description: Archaeological remains, particularly the epigraphic brick stamps, indicate a major period of construction at Portus in the late second to early third centuries AD. At this time, the Grandi Magazzini di Settimio Severo, a large warehouse, is constructed at the mouth of the hexagonal basin and a small amphitheatre is built adjoining the eastern façade of the Palazzo Imperiale. Significant phases of construction are also undertaken in other areas of the Palazzo Imperiale and in the area of the Grandi Magazzini Traianei to the south-west of the Trajanic harbour.
contentItems.title: Major Phase of Building Works Within Pre-existing Infrastructure at Portus

contentItems.description: Procopius (History of the Wars of Justinian V.26) notes that in the early sixth century AD, Portus is protected by strong walls. With commercial activity decreasing in the later fifth century AD, the functioning area of Portus retracted and focused around the hexagonal basin. Rome was still heavily dependent on imported supplies so to further protect the port from external threats, the area of the Trajanic harbour and the Darsena were enclosed within walls. The remains of these walls still exist in part around the port and have traditionally, though erroneously, been assigned a Constantinian date.
contentItems.title: Construction of a Defensive Wall to Enclose the Hexagonal Basin and Associated Buildings and Infrastructure

contentItems.description: A significant Christian population is present at Portus by the early fourth century AD. A bishop from the ‘Portus Romae’ is mentioned as having attended the Council of Arles in AD 314. In a letter written in AD 398, Saint Jerome (Epistulae LXXVII.10.1-3) refers to the establishment of a hostel at Portus to provide hospitality for Christians travellers. South of the mouth of the Trajanic harbour basin, an early form of a Christian basilica (consisting of a nave demarcated from the flanking aisles with a row of eight columns) is built in the mid-fourth century AD with further additions and renovations undertaken at the end of the fourth century through to the sixth century AD.
contentItems.title: Existence of a Bishop of Portus By This Date

contentItems.description: In the Gothic War (AD 535-553), Portus was a primary strategic location which both the Byzantines and the Ostrogoths fought to hold. General Belisarius reclaimed Rome from the Ostrogoths in AD 536 with the support of the city’s people. The Ostrogoths, led by Vittigis, made to take back the city. In AD 537, they seized Portus and, now having Rome’s crucial supply link in their possession, the Ostrogoths then besieged Rome (Procopius, History of the Wars of Justinian V.26.3-19). The siege lasted a year and resulted in disease and famine for both sides since although the Ostrogoths held Portus, the Byzantines had control of the seas. Suffering from lack of supplies, Vittigis ordered the Ostrogoths to abandon Portus which was then immediately occupied by the Isaurians (Procopius, History of the Wars of Justinian VI.7).
contentItems.title: Capture and Sack of Portus by Vittigis the Ostrogoth

contentItems.description: The Vandals led by Genseric sailed from North Africa and landed at Portus in AD 455 (Prosper, Chron. ad Ann., 455). After seizing the port, the Vandals marched on the Via Portuensis to Rome and, three days after the murder of Emperor Petronius Maximus, sacked the great city (Procopius, History of the Wars of Justinian III.5). Some historians consider this the event that marks the end of the Roman Empire.
contentItems.title: Capture of Portus by Genseric the Vandal

contentItems.description: Iron ballista bolt from a 5th century AD context at Portus
contentItems.title: Iron ballista bolt

contentItems.description: In the early fourth century AD, Portus was granted municipal status. An inscription (CIL XIV 4449) found near the Trajanic harbour and dating to AD 337-345 denotes Portus as such in a dedication to the praefectus annonae by the ordo and popuius of the Flavia Constantinianae Portuenses.
contentItems.title: Date by Which Portus Was Granted Urban Status

contentItems.description: Zosimus (VI.6) and Philostorgius (Ecclesiasticae Historiae XII.3) write that Alaric besieged and captured Portus in AD 409. The majority of the grain supply for Rome was still imported and stored at Portus at this time. By seizing Portus, Alaric threatened the Romans with starvation and certain death. The Senate capitulated to Alaric’s demands for lands and titles. However unrest and discord continued and the Visigoths seized the city of Rome in the following year, the first time the city had been sacked since 387 BC, nearly 800 years prior.
contentItems.title: Capture and Sack of Portus by Alaric the Visigoth

contentItems.description: Evidence for the deliberate demolition of the buildings at Portus
contentItems.title: Destruction of Portus buildings

contentItems.description: During the Gothic War, Rome was besieged three times: first in AD 537-538, then in AD 546 and finally in AD 549-550. The third siege resulted in the Ostrogoths, led by Totila, taking control of Rome (Procopius, History of the Wars of Justinian VIII). After Totila was defeated by Narses at the Battle of Taginae in AD 552, the remnants of the Ostrogothic force present at Rome retreated to Portus. Too few in number to defend themselves against the advancing Byzantines, the Ostrogoths surrendered and the Byzantines seized control of Portus once again.
contentItems.title: Byzantine Troops Capture Portus

contentItems.description: Marble statue of Emperor Claudius found at Gabii and currently at the Louvre Museum, Paris. (c. 1st century AD)
contentItems.title: Marble statue of Emperor Claudius

contentItems.description:
Since the fourth century BC, Rome had been served by the port of Ostia, located to the south of the mouth of the Tiber river. However Ostia’s harbour was too small to admit large ships like those which carried grain, an essential import for the populous capital. Large ships either had to dock further out and have smaller ships unload their cargo piecemeal or dock into the harbour at Pozzuoli and have the cargo unloaded and then taken overland to Rome. 
Suetonius notes (Diuus Claudius XX.1) that the creation of a large harbour to accommodate these ships was considered and then abandoned by Julius Caesar in the first century BC as too difficult an undertaking. Despite the enormity of the project and its substantial cost, Claudius initiated the construction of the large artificial harbour on the north side of the Tiber mouth in AD 42.
contentItems.title: Commencement of Construction of the Claudian Basin by Emperor Claudius

contentItems.description: Plan of the site of Portus
contentItems.title: Site plan of Portus

contentItems.description: The great imperial undertaking at Portus was not without its perils. Tacitus (Annales XV.18.3) records that a raging storm destroyed some two hundred ships within the port, a noteworthy blow to the grain supply of Rome.
contentItems.title: Destruction of C. 200 Ships During a Storm in the Claudian Basin

contentItems.description: The monumental colonnaded street which defined the western edge of the Claudian harbour (AD 42-64)
contentItems.title: Portico di Claudio

contentItems.description: Plan showing Claudian phase
contentItems.title: Claudian phase

contentItems.description: Sestertius of Nero (RIC 1, no. 178) minted in c. AD 64 showing the Claudian harbour on the reverse
contentItems.title: Coin commemorated by Nero

contentItems.description: The construction of the Claudian port took two decades to complete. A bronze coin issued in AD 64 commemorates the inauguration of the harbour at Portus under the emperor Nero. However the planning and construction of Portus appear to have been organized in such a way as to enable the harbour to function at a very early date as evidenced by the presence and destruction of two hundred ships in the harbour two years previous. Also Pliny the Elder (Naturalis Historia IX.5.14-15) relates the story of Claudius trapping a killer whale at Portus by closing off the mouth of the harbour with nets and then engaging it in combat.
contentItems.title: Inauguration of Portus - Commemorated With a Special Coin Issue Showing the Claudian Basin

contentItems.description: The first-century bath complex (c. 40 m by 30 m) was comprised of multiple vaulted rooms of brick-faced concrete construction.
contentItems.title: Visual reconstruction of the Terme Della Lanterna

timeline.title: U of T Faculty of Law

contentItems.attribution: U of T Libraries, Fisher Library, Digital Collections
contentItems.description: In 1923, Frederick Grant Banting and John James Rickard Macleod were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for their discovery of insulin at the University of Toronto. Banting chose to share half of the prize money with his colleague, Charles Best, who was not recognized for his work.
contentItems.title: Frederick Banting and Charles Best

exhibits.title: Nobel Prize for the discovery of insulin

timeline.title: U of T Faculty of Medicine

contentItems.attribution: Uploaded to Microsoft Photosynth by Core5
contentItems.description: iConference 2012 represented a true bellwether event, providing further evidence of the international nature of the iSchools movement. Conducted in Toronto under unseasonably mild and sunny skies, the well-attended conference provided an excellent networking environment for the gathered representatives of the information community, while at the same time offering a high-quality program consisting of the very best selections from the record-level of submissions received.
contentItems.title: Toronto iConference 2012

timeline.title: U of T Faculty of Information
U of T Faculty of Applied Science and Engineering

contentItems.attribution: 1675 Petition to Gov. Berkeley - Available at the Library of Virginia (virginiamemory.com)
contentItems.description: n 1641, King Charles I appointed William Berkeley governor of Virginia colony, a position he held for most of the next thirty-five years. Berkeley was an elitist who had little sympathies with lower-class settlers. Under Berkeley, commoners paid the greatest tax burdens, while elites reaped the greatest rewards. The wealthiest and most ambitious planters did well under Berkeley because they received the largest and most land grants, licenses to trade with Indians for deerskins, and the best public offices. So when frontiersmen led by Bacon rose in genocidal anger against Indians, Berkeley moved to prevent their actions, not because of his sympathies for Indians, but because an Indian war would undermine a key source of profit -- the deerskin trade -- for elites. After Bacon’s Rebellion, King Charles II blamed Berkeley and the colony’s elites for the troubles, believing that they had pushed common planters too hard. The king recalled Berkeley, replacing him with a new governor. Within a year of losing his governorship, Berkeley died before he could plead his case in front of the king.
contentItems.title: William Berkeley

contentItems.attribution: Brinkman's Arrest of Nathaniel Bacon, 1904 - Available at Encyclopedia Virginia (encyclopediavirginia.org)
contentItems.description: Nathaniel Bacon came to Virginia as a member of a well-connected English family. Although he was Cambridge-educated and quick-witted, Bacon became embroiled in a swindle, which prompted his father to send him packing to Virginia. Governor Berkeley, Bacon’s cousin by marriage, initially appointed the young gentleman to the governor’s council; however, the ambitious newcomer turned against his patron, whom he saw as old and ineffective. After a group of Indians murdered his overseer on his estate along the James River, Bacon began leading groups of armed volunteers to attack Indians. His defiance of the hated Governor Berkeley earned him more support among the common planters on the frontier. However, Bacon quickly learned that he had little control over the angry mob that saw him as their leader. His sudden death from dysentery resulted in the collapse of the rebellion.
contentItems.title: Nathaniel Bacon

contentItems.attribution: Louis Nicolas' Susquehannock (1675) from His Codex Canadiensis
contentItems.description:
The Susquehannocks, an Iroquoian-speaking people, were not part of the powerful Haudenosaunee League during the seventeenth century. Instead, they were allies of the Hurons, another Iroquoian-speaking group who were enemies of the Haudenosaunee. For decades in the early to mid-seventeenth century, the Susquehannocks had controlled the flow of furs in the Pennsylvania area. They funneled furs from allies in the Ohio River Valley to European traders. Because of their position, they exchanged furs with French, English, and Dutch traders, which enabled them to get any kind and amount of firearms they wanted. One of their villages even had a cannon. This made them valuable allies of the Hurons and hated enemies of the Haudenosaunee.
Once the Haudenosaunee League had finished hammering Indians in the Ohio River Valley, they turned their attention to the Susquehannocks in the 1660s. And with the Ohio Valley then in the hands of the league, Susquehannocks had lost their steady supply of furs, which ended their privileged trade status with European traders and the supply of firearms they provided. Additionally, European diseases had devastated the Susquehannocks, so they could offer little resistance to the more powerful Haudenosaunee warriors who pushed them into the colony of Maryland. Although the colonial governor welcomed the Susquehannocks to Maryland, local colonists did not. A 1,000-man armed mob -- led by John Washington, the great-grandfather of George Washington -- attacked the Susquehannocks in 1675, pushing them into the Virginia frontier on the same lands north of the York River that the defeated Powhatans lived in and that young planters led by Nathaniel Bacon desired. These circumstances explain why the Susquehannocks, originally from Pennsylvania, were living in the Virginia frontier at the time of Bacon’s Rebellion.
contentItems.title: Susquehannock Refugees

contentItems.description:
The boundary line settled at the end of the Powhatan Wars did not hold. The colonists’ population continued to grow. Newcomers wanted lands for tobacco plantations, but land south of the York River -- part of the boundary line separating Powhatans from English -- was expensive and had been bought up by colonists of means. New colonists were especially eager to get their own land because this was the key to gaining the right to vote in colonial matters. So these settlers began to view land held by the Powhatans as the answer to their problems.
The conflict began during the summer of 1675, when a Virginia planter refused to pay Doeg Indians for some trade goods they had provided. The Doegs appropriated some of the planter’s hogs and fled north across the York River into Powhatan lands. The planter raised a force of neighboring settlers, and they crossed the river in pursuit of the Doegs. When this posse came across some refugee Susquehannocks, they murdered them because they were eager to punish “thieving” Indians… and any Indians would do, at that point. The Susquehannocks retaliated, killing the planter’s son and several others, and more raids followed.
Local colonists assembled a militia and wanted to attack all Indians north of the York River. They saw this as an opportunity to not only punish Indians, but also as a chance to seize their land. The colony’s governor at the time, William Berkeley, refused to allow them to do this. Instead, he proposed that the colony build a string of defensive forts along the south shore of the York River that would help to keep Indians out and colonists on their side of the boundary line. Many colonists did not like this because this would mean that their taxes would be raised to pay for the expensive forts, in addition to the lost opportunity to take more Indian land.
The following spring (1676) a group of impatient planters persuaded Nathaniel Bacon to take matters in his own hands. Bacon raised a force of 300 men to wage a war of extermination against all Indians. Gov. Berkeley declared Bacon a rebel, yet Bacon and his militia headed across the river and killed some Indians. This “victory” prompted local planters to appoint Bacon to the colony’s representative assembly. In June, Bacon arrived at Jamestown with 500 armed men and bullied the assembly into granting him a commission to kill Indians. Once he and his militia left, however, the governor once again named him a rebel.
Bacon’s militia slaughtered some friendly Pamunkey Indians, before returning to Jamestown to deal with Berkeley. They attacked the colony’s capital and burned it down in September. The rebellion fell apart, though, when Bacon suddenly died from dysentery in October. In January 1677, 1,000 British soldiers landed and restored order to the colony.
contentItems.title: Rebelling for the Right to Kill Indians

contentItems.attribution: Map of the Powhatan Chiefdom - from Helen C. Rountree, Available on Encyclopedia Virginia (encyclopediavirginia.org)
contentItems.description: Powhatans called the coastal plain of what is today North Carolina and Virginia Tsenacommacah. This was the land of the Powhatan Confederacy. It stretched north to the Potomac River, south to the Neuse River and included Chesapeake Bay, Albemarle Sound, and Pamilco Sound. When the English arrived in 1607, Werowocomoco (about ten miles from Jamestown) was the capital of the Powhatan Confederacy.
contentItems.title: Tsenacommacah

contentItems.attribution: John White's "The Manner of Their Fishing," 1585 - Available on Virtual Jamestown (virtualjamestown.org)
contentItems.description: Powhatans are an Algonquian people. In the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, they followed a seasonal subsistence lifestyle, typical of many Algonquians. Families lived in specific winter villages and dispersed in the spring to gather food. They returned to their villages in the summer to harvest the Three Sisters (corn, bean, and squash) and dispersed again in the fall to hunt and gather. Their way of life provided for their communities but generated small surpluses. This meant that there was little to tide them over during poor harvests or when additional pressures were put on their food sources.
contentItems.title: Algonquian Seasonal Subsistence Pattern

contentItems.attribution: "Detail of a Map of Virginia of 1612, Showing Powhatan in the Royal Wigwam," by Robert Vaughn - Available at Library of Congres (loc.gov)
contentItems.description: The man who became Powhatan was born as Wahunsonacock around 1550. He inherited six tribes when he assumed the role as chief, and by the early seventeenth century, he had expanded his domain to thirty tribes, which included perhaps as many as 100 villages and 24,000 people. Powhatan had a reputation for exercising fear, power, and a bit of treachery. He consolidated power by conferring chiefdoms on his relatives and marrying daughters of chiefs in his confederacy -- he had twelve (or possibly thirteen) wives by 1607. Powhatan united the disparate tribes and villages of Tsenacommacah by channeling the energy of the confederacy’s warriors outward to nearby enemies. Originally, these were the Monacan and Manahoac Indians -- later, the invading colonists.
contentItems.title: Powhatan's Rise to Power

contentItems.attribution: Theodor de Bry's "A Weroans, or Chieftain, of Virginia," 1590, Available at the Library of Congress (loc.gov)
contentItems.description:
When the English arrived in 1607, they encountered Native peoples of the Powhatan Confederacy. This complex polity arose in the Chesapeake during the 1570s and was composed of a number of tribes and villages under the authority of one chief, Powhatan. At its height in the early seventeenth century, the Powhatan Confederacy included perhaps as many as 100 villages and 24,000 people. The village was the administrative unit of the confederacy, and they paid 80% of their wealth to Powhatan as tribute.
Each village had several layers of governance. The cockarouse was the first person of dignity in a village. The village elected him or her (women could become cockarouses) to this office for life. Cockarouses exercised authority during times of peace and were in charge of all public and private concerns in a village. They presided over the tribal council and were delegates to Powhatan’s council. Villages also had a weroance, whom Powhatan appointed. These officers were also members of Powhatan’s council. They led hunting and fishing expeditions and were in charge of all military affairs. Weroances exercised the power of life and death over village members and collected tribute due to Powhatan. Each village also had a priest, who was another member of Powhatan’s council. Additionally, tribes (usually composed of several villages) had their own councils that regulated matters of concern for the entire body.
Powhatan shared his authority over the confederacy with his council, the Matchacomoco, which was composed of cockarouses, weroances, and priests from all the villages. The people of the confederacy convened the Matchacomoco, which held open meetings, declared war or peace, conducted foreign relations, and managed domestic affairs at the confederacy level. Decisions made by the Matchacomoco required unanimity, although Powhatan greatly affected council policy. This was the political entity that encountered the English in the seventeenth century.
contentItems.title: Complex Leadership Organization

contentItems.description: Born in 1545, Opechancanough was the older brother of Powhatan. When the colonists arrived in 1607, Opechancanough was the weroance of the Pamunkey tribe, a smaller tribe that paid tribute to Powhatan. He had been the one to capture John Smith and bring him to Powhatan. Opechancanough was no friend of the English. When he became paramount chief, he intended to reverse his brother’s accommodations to the English. Three specific factors had hardened his anger against the English: the deadly impact of European crowd diseases on his people, English efforts at assimilating his people, and, most importantly, the colonists’ encroachments upon Native lands.
contentItems.title: Opechancanough

contentItems.attribution: Theodor de Bry's "Pocahontas Taken Prisoner," 1618 - Available at Library of Congress (loc.gov)
contentItems.description: Born in 1595 or 1596, Pocahontas was one of perhaps twelve daughters and twenty sons of Powhatan, the paramount chief of the tens of thousands of people who lived in Tsenacommacah, their name for the Virginia tidewater that became the English colony of Virginia. After initially amicable relations, the English and Powhatans fell into conflict as starving colonists began demanding and stealing food from local Native communities. The violence continued to escalate until 1613 with the capture of Pocahontas by the English. As a hostage in Jamestown she received indoctrination in Christianity under the supervision of Deputy Governor Thomas Dale, an authoritarian official who punished colonists by hanging them, burning them, shooting them dead, or breaking them upon the wheel.
contentItems.title: Capture of Pocahontas

contentItems.attribution: 1867 Lithograph - Available at Library of Congress (loc.gov)
contentItems.description: Around the age of eighteen, Pocahontas met John Rolfe, a young twenty-eight-year-old bachelor who became smitten with her. Rolfe proposed marriage in 1614, and both Dale and Powhatan saw this as a smart diplomatic move because it would become a possible bridge for peace between their peoples. When Pocahontas accepted Rolfe’s proposal and went to live among the English, she did not abandon her culture. Instead her actions should be understood as an attempt to incorporate the English into her Algonquian world, to make it possible for them to live in Tsenacommacah by Powhatan rules, something that was often done through important marriages like hers.
contentItems.title: Wedding of Pocahontas with John Rolfe

contentItems.attribution: Hand-Colored Engraving of Powhatans and English Colonists by Reys van Martin Pringe (1625) - Available at Encyclopedia Virginia (encyclopediavirginia.org)
contentItems.description:
After accepting the English demands at the end of the Powhatan War in 1632, Opechancanough hid his resentment for a time and encouraged colonists to spread out. He hoped this would make them more vulnerable to attack sometime later. That moment came on April 18, 1644, when Opechancanough led a second surprise attack on the colony. Nearly 100 years old, crippled and blind, the leader of the Powhatan Confederacy still led his troops, even though they carried him to battle on a litter. The initial attack had an even higher number of casualties than the one in 1622. Opechancanough’s warriors killed nearly 500 colonists. But this represented a much smaller percentage of the English population. By then, 8,000 colonists lived in Virginia.
The Powhatan Confederacy had a hard time mounting a serious, long-term offensive at this time because they had been seriously weakened by disease. English counterattacks destroyed most of the towns of the confederacy, and the uprising ended when Opechancanough was seized. English authorities placed him in jail in Jamestown, and two weeks later, an angry guard shot him dead. The victorious English then dictated to the Powhatans a boundary line that pushed them even further out of Tsenacommacah.
contentItems.title: Opechancanough's Second Surprise Attack on English Colonists

contentItems.attribution: "Slaves Working in Seventeenth-Century Virginia," 1670 - Available at LearnNC (learnnc.org)
contentItems.description: The Virginia Company brought slavery to Jamestown in 1619, when they imported twenty African slaves. Tobacco plantations needed large amounts of labor, more than indentured servants could provide. As Africans, slaves had no protections under English law. Unlike indentured servitude, the terms of a slave’s service never expired -- slavery was permanent, unless the master freed him or her. African slaves were better than Indian slaves because the latter kept dying from diseases or ran away into the woods. Moreover, their skin color made slaves stand out, which made them easier to catch when they ran away. Toward the end of the seventeenth century, slaves supplanted indentured servants in the Chesapeake.
contentItems.title: Slaves

contentItems.attribution: Indenture Contract - Available at Virtual Jamestown (virtualjamestown.org)
contentItems.description: Two-thirds of the English colonists who arrived in the seventeenth century came as indentured servants. They were the ones the wealthier people hired to work the land. Indentured servants labored for five to seven years in return for their passage across the Atlantic. They lacked many basic rights and could be punished physically. Indentured servitude was no guarantee of eventual success. Many died during their terms due to being overworked and falling prey to disease. Additionally, when the term of their indenture was up, most still still did not have money to buy land. So their choices were to indenture themselves for another long period to get the money to purchase land or to strike off into the dangerous frontier where powerful Powhatans still lived.
contentItems.title: Indentured Servants

contentItems.attribution: "Martin's Best Virginia at the Tobacco Role in Bloombury Markett," Available at British Museum (britishmuseum.org)
contentItems.description: During its first decade, Jamestown struggled to become a profitable colony. Lacking the mineral wealth of Spanish colonies to the south and the lucrative furs of the French colony far to the north, Jamestown seemed to lag far behind. In 1616, though, the colony found what eventually became the foundation of its financial success -- tobacco. John Rolfe introduced the future cash crop to Virginia, and it thrived in the long, hot and humid growing season. When Jamestown transitioned from a private company to a Crown colony in 1624, the monarchy supported tobacco cultivation because they could tax it and make money. Tobacco had become so popular in Europe that this crop became what gold was for the Spanish - its economic lifeblood. By 1700, Virginia was growing thirty million pounds of tobacco annually. This meant that the colony developed as a rural place with huge plantations and few large towns. Additionally, the money made from tobacco attracted more settlers, boosting the colony’s white population to 100,000 by 1700. But what this cash crop needed -- land and labor -- exacted a catastrophic toll on the Powhatans and imported African slaves.
contentItems.title: 1616: Introduction of Tobacco

contentItems.attribution: "Pocahontas at the Court of King James," 1907 Print - Available at the Library of Congress (loc.gov)
contentItems.description: In 1616, John Rolfe, Pocahontas (then called Rebecca), and their infant son traveled to England, accompanied by perhaps as many as ten Powhatans. This was a publicity tour paid for by the Virginia Company. Early in 1617, Pocahontas was received at the court of King James I; however, she died two months later of some unidentified ailment. With her died the hopes for peaceful ethnic relations symbolized by her marriage to Rolfe.
contentItems.title: 1617: Death of Pocahontas in England

contentItems.attribution: "Indian Charnel House," Watercolor by John White, 1585-86 - Available at Virtual Jamestown (virtualjamestown.org)
contentItems.description: Shortly after Pocahontas’s death in England, Powhatan died. We do not know what he died from or any details of his death. Similar to other chiefs, his body was disemboweled and placed on a scaffold. Three years later, after his body had decomposed, his bones were collected in a bundle and deposited ceremonially in a temple at Uttamussak. A large number of people attended this final ceremony, including dignitaries from Jamestown. With Powhatan’s passing, a continuation of amicable ties between the colonists and Powhatans became even less likely as the reins of power passed to Powhatan’s brother Opechancanough.
contentItems.title: April 1618: Death of Powhatan

contentItems.attribution: "Pocahontas Saving the Life of Cpat. John Smith," 1870 Lithograph - Available at the Library of Congress (loc.gov)
contentItems.description:
Nearly everyone is familiar with the myth of Pocahontas and John Smith. As memorialized by Disney, Pocahontas supposedly saved Smith’s life from her murderous and powerful father, Powhatan. However, little more could be further from the truth. As the colonists in Jamestown starved, they began to demand more food from the Powhatans, even stealing when the Indians balked at exchanging more than their communities could afford to trade. When Powhatans caught colonists stealing, they killed them, such as the time they executed seventeen English thieves, stuffed their mouths with corn (as a sign of contempt), and left their corpses outside Jamestown for their countrymen to find.
As colonists retaliated with increasingly harsher episodes of violence, the situation threatened to spiral out of control. With tens of thousands of Powhatans potentially arrayed against a handful of starving English, Jamestown’s leaders knew they needed to do something to end of violence. Familiar with the Spanish tactic of conquering indigenous communities by seizing paramount chiefs, John Smith set out to capture Powhatan. Instead, Powhatan captured the bumbling Englishman, and the chief saw an opportunity. He staged a mock execution that Pocahontas, one of his thirty-two children, interrupted at her father’s instructions. But this was no actual execution, as Smith mistakenly thought; it was an adoption ceremony. Powhatan hoped that adopting Smith would bring the troublesome newcomers under his control, help bring peace, and restore the once profitable trade in English goods.
Like many encounters, misunderstanding on both sides marred this event. Powhatan misunderstood Smith’s gratitude for being alive as consent to his terms: thieving colonists would be controlled, regular tribute would come to Powhatan, and trade would resume. On the other hand, Smith misunderstood the ritual, framing it long after the fact as an incident in which the chief’s thoughtful daughter (then famous in England) had intervened to save his life. After his release, Smith went back to bullying Indians for food and intermittent warfare continued.
contentItems.title: John Smith & Pocahontas

contentItems.attribution: "First Legislative Assembly" - Available at Nat'l Parks Service Historic Jamestown (nps.gov/jame)
contentItems.description: The high death toll during Jamestown’s early years earned the colony a reputation as more of a slaughterhouse than a place to live. The Virginia Company decided that they needed some unique enticements to encourage colonists to continue emigrating to the colony. In 1618, they introduced the headright system, a policy that gave fifty acres of land to a colonist who paid for his own or another’s passage. This meant that those who could afford to bring many servants with them acquired large parcels of land. In 1619, the company established the House of Burgess, the first elected assembly in colonial North America. In this assembly, only landowners could voted. However, the House of Burgess enjoyed limited power because the Virginia Company retained the right to nullify any of their acts. Despite this limitation, though, this was an important development because it created a precedent that all English colonies eventually followed.
contentItems.title: Headright System & the House of Burgess

contentItems.attribution: Photo of Skull with Cannibalism Marks - Available at Richmond Times-Dispatch (timesdispatch.com)
contentItems.description: The colonists experienced great difficulty during the early years at Jamestown. Their first challenge was to simply survive, and seventeenth-century North America was a dangerous place for Englishmen. The colonists had made a serious error in placing their settlement near a malarial swamp, a situation they compounded by dumping trash and excrement in the river. The resultant typhus and dysentery, along with malarial chills, hit the initial population hard. Early colonists were more interested in finding wealth than in farming. As John Smith noted, the settlers “would rather starve than work.” And starve they did. Of the initial 104 colonists, only 38 remained alive nine months later. New arrivals in 1609 boosted their population to 220, but after a harsh winter, only 60 remained alive. The situation had indeed turned grim when one colonist killed and ate his wife, a crime for which his peers found him guilty and burned him at the stake. The only condition that kept Jamestown growing during the initial years was the regular shipment of new settlers by the Virginia Company. By 1622, they had transported approximately 10,000 people to the colony, but only 20 percent of these were still alive in 1622.
contentItems.title: A Struggle for Survival

contentItems.attribution: Charter of the Virginia Company, 1606 - Available at Library of Congress (loc.gov)
contentItems.description: Setting a pattern that became common for English colonization in North America, the English monarchy did not directly sponsor Jamestown in the beginning.
